dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hot wind kicks up plumes of sand. MUSIC rises as we SWE across endless dunes, TRIBAL DRUMS pounding in the distan

dialogues.speaker: BEGIN MAIN TITLES
dialogues.text: We CLIP the crest of a dune. Down, and up another. A BOY’S VOICE In this strange and forbidding world, one creature walks alone. We stop on a four-toed footprint, filling with sand. Just WHISTLE of the wind. And then, a keening CRY. A CLAW breaks through the sand. Giant, reptilian. The who body crashes over the rise, tail slashing across the dune eyes swivel in separate directions. A BOY’S VOICE He follows a compass only he can see, to a place he does not know. A WHITE WORM falls from the orange sky, wriggling as it h sand. The lizard’s thick tongue shoots out. Sucks it in. The DRUMS thunder as we look up to the heavens, where a g face stares down at us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking into the terrarium, eleven-year old BILLY FORREST drops another meal worm down on the iguana, making approp ALIEN MONSTER noises.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: He has taken the sacrifice! The village is saved! His two-year old SISTER watches wide-eyed from the doorwa She's spoiling the mood.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Go away, Katie. Amscray. She doesn’t budge. Ignoring her, Billy rifles through num packing boxes. Gives up his search.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pristine New England town, picketfenceville. Washed car well-groomed lawns. The kind of place where everyone gets New Yorker, and not just for the cartoons. Afternoon heat rises off the streets, stick-to-your-back Billy ducks under a couch as MOVERS carry it in. Katie do heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dusty and sweating, Billy’s mom CHRISTINE slides a heavy across the floor. She’s young and athletic. At the moment exhausted. Billy looks in over the sill.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Mom, where are my comic books?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Your dad has the list. Are you watching Katie? He’s already gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrying a giant box, a DIMWITTED MOVER bumps into the ma Blocked, he pushes harder and harder, bending back the po Finally Billy’s dad MITCH rescues him, directing him towa house.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: That goes in the kitchen. The room with the sink and the stove. (beat) Just put it anywhere. The Mover Guy trudges through the flowers, heading for th house. Three other NEIGHBORHOOD FATHERS stand near Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: So if your wife is the new principal, what do you do?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Well you know, that. That is something we're figuring out. I’m figuring out. MR. SAINT-CLAIRE’s videocamera WHIRS as he zooms out. He’ taping everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s for that video show. You know, the $100,000 grand prize.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE JACKSON
dialogues.text: He tapes everything. You figure somebody's gotta fall down sometime. Billy tugs on his dad’s sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Dad, where are my comic books?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: My son Billy.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Hi. Hi. Hi. Where?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (checks list) Box 19. I think it’s inside already. Billy takes off. He points a finger back at Katie.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Stay. Katie pouts.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Nineteen...nineteen. We follow Billy as he sweeps through the rooms. In the background, the Mover Guy falls backward,

dialogues.speaker: CRASHING
dialogues.text: through a picture window. His PAL hurries over to help. M Saint-Claire rushes in with his videocamera. Billy spots promising box. Turns it to find then number. Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy pokes through the boxes, nothing. He looks out the at the quiet, boring treelined street. Just a little wist That’s when he sees A BLACK KID his age jump the fence in back yard. He starts filling two squirtguns from the Forr  hose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy walks out to the kid, who hasn’t seen him. He’s abo say something when the water-gunman turns on him. The kid JACKSON, has a smear of blue paint across his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Blue or red?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I dunno. We just moved in. Tom considers this for a second.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You’re blue now. He wipes some of the paint off his forehead and onto Bill Hands him one of the squirtguns.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Red controls Maple, Ash and Pine. We lose Hickory and it’s all over. Billy stares at his gun, confused. Hands it back.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Hold on. He races back inside the house. Tom follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hidden behind two other boxes, Billy finds box 19. He rip open, digging out the Super Soaker 9000, an impressive pi water-fighting technology.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Man, where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (cocks it) Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We RISE over the roof to reveal the neighborhood, a check of back yards. Red Team BOYS by the dozen climb fences, a headed our direction. It’s the mother of all water fights

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of boys race across the grass, some charging, some fleeing for their lives. Mitch holds a TV up out of the stampede. Katie grabs his leg tight. A KID dives under th van. Christine dodges a stray waterballoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VARIOUS SHOTS: The Blue Team tries to stem the charge of Red Brigade. Hoses spray, water balloons fly. A garbage c full of water floods a blue bunker. Innocent house pets r their lives. But everyone plays fair -- dead men get out way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO BOYS charge in from the back patio, disturbing THREE looking through magazines. As the boys take off through t house, two TWO OTHER BOYS chase them, guns drawn. The gir SCREAM at them to get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALAN SAINT-CLAIRE, a Red Team sugar addict with Charlie M eyes, fills a water balloon way beyond its recommended threshold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy and Tom race through the yard. Suddenly, three tras lids pop up. Red Team kids stand, firing. Caught in the crossfire, Billy and Tom do their best Miami Vice -- roll jumping and diving for cover. A KID ON THE ROOF throws a water balloon at Billy. He cat it. Throws it back. Tom charges the line, firing like a madman. Billy pegs a SNIPER who had a lock on Tom. The ya clear.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Tom Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Billy Forrester. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan keeps filling his water balloon, now swollen to the a state fair pumpkin.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. STORM CELLAR
dialogues.text: A small COWLICKED KID watches through the cracks as JOE M walks past, alone. Joe is the Jon Gotti of the fifth grad a good argument for steroids testing in Little League. The Cowlicked Kid rushes out with a kamikaze charge, eyes closed, firing. Keeps shooting until his pistol runs dry. Opens his eyes. Joe towers over him, big enough to block sun. His shirt is soaked.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You didn’t get me. Got it? The Cowlicked Kid nods.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Gimme your shirt. The Cowlicked Kid peels off his beloved Mr. Bubble shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan ties off the knot on his water balloon, the neutron water warfare. It’s the size of a beanbag chair, rubber s shimmering and translucent. He has to bend backwards to c it, walking right past

dialogues.speaker: BILLY AND TOM,
dialogues.text: who stare in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hey Alan! Alan jerks around, trying to see past the balloon. He tri his legs and falls on his masterpiece, drenched.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Nevermind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Racing ahead, Billy and Tom are surprised by THREE HEADS up on either side. In the nick of time, everyone realizes they’re on the same team -- blue paint all around. WEEZER climbs over the fence, double-husky shorts TEARIN lands.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Weezer, who else we got?

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: This is it, man. We’re gettin’ slaughtered. Another kid (HICKS) rips off duct tape with his teeth. GE tapes Weezer’s shorts closed.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: Who's the kid?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Billy Forrester. We just moved into the house on Sycam...

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Yo, Batman. We don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Weezer, Hicks -- bring ‘em around. Operation Graveyard has begun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, Tom and Gelman crouch at a water spigot, re-fillin

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Who decides decides who’s on whose team?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Joe McGuire.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Why him?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Because everybody wants to be on his team. Refilled, Tom goes off to find cover.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: Joe McGuire’s the best, number one, no question. But everyone was on his team, who would he kill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weezer WHEEZES as he drops down for cover. Tom checks the mark on his back.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Not hit. Sweating. He points to his soaking armpit. Keeps wheezing.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Far side. Heading this way. In the distance, we hear kids YELLING.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: That’d be them. EXT. PAUPER’S FIELD - DAY A flat, open section with only head plates, no monuments cover. Hicks runs for his life, the entire red team on hi butt. He takes a shot from behind, falling in Platoon-lik agony.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Hey pansy whackers! Jackson! Come out and take it like a man. Previously soaked kids and other ONLOOKERS gather at the of the field to watch the battle. The Cowlicked Kid is conspicuously shirtless.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THE MONUMENTS
dialogues.text: Tom stands. The other three follow.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: (to Billy) That’s Joe.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Is that all you got? You’re screwed! On the red side, teams of three stretch out innertube har - super slingshots. They load in waterballoons. Weezer turns his back to the enemy. Drops his shorts to m them.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Blast ‘em.  A hundred water balloons fill the sky.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Cover! The boys duck behind gravestones and trash can lids. Ball rain down like hailstones, relentless POUNDING. Gelman ta hit that knocks off his glasses. Weezer gets hit by three torrent stops. Billy peeks out from under his shield. He’ and alive. Tom stands.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Watch out! Tom looks up to see one last red balloon. No time to run. hits him smack in the face. He’s soaked. Joe and friends CHEER.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We still got a man left!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Who? Tom waves for Billy to stand up, He does, nervously.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Billy. (more confidently) Billy Forrester. MURMURING at the side of the field -- who is this guy? Th Teamers start to reload.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Say “challenge.”

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Challenge.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Shout it! Quick! No time to think, Billy shouts...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Ch--CHALLENGE! His voice ECHOES. The spectator kids lean forward with an OOOO000H as the obscure rule is enacted. Discuss among themselves. Joe shakes his head sadly.  10.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (paranoid) What’d I just do?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You called challege, so you gotta face Joe down man-to-man in a duel. You only get one shot. So don’t blow it. We walks to the side, leaving Billy alone in his panic. F the far end of the field, Joe walks toward him. Finally B starts to close the distance. We PUSH IN on Billy as he walks, nervous and sweating. As regains his composure, we PULL OUT. We are now in Billyvi (trademarked)...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dust, wind and rattlesnakes. Tom’s spurs JANGLE as he joi other FRONTIER KIDS at the store front railing. From the end of the corral, Joe approaches. Billy meets him halfwa His eye twitches.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Never seen ya ‘round these parts. A tongue-flick moves a matchstick to the other side of hi mouth.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (Eastwoodian) Are we gonna chit-chat, or are we gonna do this?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: On ten. Billy and Joe stand back to back. They start their counte march. One. Two.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Seventeen! Nine! Infinity!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Seven.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Eight.  11.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Nine. Ten! Billy turns and draws, lightning fast. Fires. But all tha comes out is a lonely WHISTLE of air. Panicking, he looks the bottom of the Super Soaker. The T-shaped stopper dangles as the last of the water DRI Pulling out of CLOSE UP, we are --

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Eat water. The Uzi blasts like God’s WaterPik. Billy is drenched. Tom and company are disappointed, but not surprised. The Team CHEERS, along with more than a few traitorous Blue T As Joe walks past, even The Cowlicked Kid CLAPS for him. Joe is safely past, the Kid kicks the grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four sneakers SQUISH as Billy and Tom walk home.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I coulda taken him.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We'll never know. Billy and Tom bump fists. Tom SQUISHES off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch and Christine try to fit a giant blue couch through narrow doorway. It’s no good.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: If we tip it up on its side and slide it...OUCH! Ouch! He’s pinned against the doorframe. Billy comes in from ou starts climbing the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Where have you been?  12.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Meeting the neighbors. His sneakers SQUISH with each step. They’re about to ask, decide against it. INT. BILLY’S ROOM - NIGHT Katie runs past SQUEALING in the hallway, wet and shampoo Mitch chases after her. Christine helps Billy unpack.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Where do you want to put your toys?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Mom, fourth graders have toys. Fifth graders have stuff.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: I apologize. They unload a box into the closet.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: This is the first time you and I have been at the same school. Are you okay with me being your principal?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: It's cool. I mean, it’s not like anybody's going to know.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Honey, I think people are going to figure it out. We have the same last name. We live in the same house. Billy has never considered this. He nods,

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I could use an alias, and you could park in the garage.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Just don't think you have to act any differently because I'm your mom. Promise me you'll just be yourself. okay. Christine holds up a tattered sock monkey.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: What about Mr. Bobo?  13.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Give him to Katie. I don’t care. He’s lying, but she’s too cool to call him on it. She hea the door.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Get to bed. We have school tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (at door) Night, sport. As they shut the door, we see Billy is visibly troubled. INT. KATIE’S ROOM - NIGHT Christine tucks Mr. Bobo beside a sleeping Katie. Mitch t it back out, suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Wait. You just had some kind of parental bonding experience with Billy, didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: It’s not a competition, Mitch. He nods -- he can see right through her ruse.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I’11 admit I’m down, but don’t count me out. I’ma rally-er. Mitch Forrester rallies. He strikes a Heisman Trophy pose, blocking and dodging, f “scoring.” He’s about to spike Mr. Bobo when he notices Christine has left. He tucks in the monkey and goes. INT. BILLY’S ROOM / HIGH ANGLE - NIGHT A breeze stirs the curtains. Billy has dozed off, his sta horror comics slipping one-by-one off the nightstand. His flashlight CLUNKS to the floor, the beam spotlighting a p a comic book. We PUSH IN on the page. It is animated within each panel. INT. BILLY’S ROOM / HIGH ANGLE - ANIMATION ANIMATED BILLY lies asleep in bed.  14.

dialogues.speaker: THE VOICE
dialogues.text: Billy Forrester seemed like an ordinary boy. CLOSE-UP: Animated Billy asleep.

dialogues.speaker: THE VOICE
dialogues.text: But he had a terrible secret. A secret that would haunt him for the rest of his life. Animated Billy's eyes shoot open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A heavy door CLANGS shut behind Animated Billy. The hallw crowded with dozens of kids milling about. They all turn stare at him. He adjusts his backpack and starts walking through the pack. CLOSE-UP: Animated Billy, nervous, almost paranoid. CLOSE-UP: Kids watching, sizing him up. Two BOYS are chasing each other. They run past Billy, bru against him.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (to himself) No, please. Not now! But it's too late. His torso begins shaking. The backpack slips off. The shirt begins tearing off. A second head bu out of his shoulder. It's Christine. Her head flails arou eyes wide and maniacal. CHRISTINE’S HEAD Stop running in the halls! Spit out that gum! Do you want detention? The kids stare in horror.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Oh my God! He’s a freak! Pandemonium. Kids bolt in every direction.

dialogues.speaker: ANIMATED BILLY
dialogues.text: No, wait! ANIMATED JOE is the last into the classroom. He waves as shuts the door. The hallway is empty.  15. CHRISTINE’S HEAD You’re not mad are you? Give your mommy some kisses. He tries to fend her off.

dialogues.speaker: THE VOICE
dialogues.text: And so began the horrible curse of... Dum-dum-DUM! A title sweeps over...

dialogues.speaker: THE VOICE
dialogues.text: Principal Boy. INT. BILLY’S ROOM - NIGHT The flesh-and-blood Billy jerks awake. Hops out of bed, disoriented. He pulls his shirt up over his shoulder. Che in the mirror. No mutant head. Whew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful Maxwell House morning. Birds SING. Sprinklers HISS. Mitch opens the front door to see the newspaper flying st at him. He catches it one-handed. Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch climbs over the blue couch, which hasn’t moved. Kat coming down the stairs, dragging the sock monkey behind h

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Guess you and me are the early birds, huh? She climbs on his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch is gluing together an IKEA entertainment center. Ka watches.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Three, four, five... He’s out of pegs with one hole left. He checks around  16. everywhere. Finally Katie points to the back of his arm. peels the peg off, continues construction.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: See, a lot of guys would feel threatened by this situation. I mean, your mom earning all the money. The piece doesn’t fit right. He bangs it until it goes in MITCH (CONT’D) You probably didn’t know this, but in Japanese, the word for “crisis” is the same as “opportunity.” If the business hadn't fallen apart, your mom wouldn’t have been able to take this amazing job and I wouldn’t have gotten this chance to spend more time with you and Billy. Katie hands him the allen wrench. MITCH (CONT’D) For instance, this afternoon you and me are going fishing. When was the last time somebody went fishing in Los Angeles? The final screw tightened, he stands back to admire his creation. Puts a book on the shelf to christen it. Katie CLAPS.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Why thank you. He carries her out of the room. We hang back for a second book falls over. The entire unit slants to the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaos. A swirl of bodies fighting for floorspace. The microwave BEEPS. Billy dumps his cereal bowl in the sink.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH AND CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Water! Billy goes back and runs water in the bowl. Mitch is chop up a banana for Katie. Christine does one last check.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Are you going to be alright?  17.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Grocery list. Alphabetized. Beeper. On. Wife. Late.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: I’m going. Billy, are you riding with me?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (panicked) No!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Okay. (kneeling) One last thing. What are you going to do today? Beeeee....

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Myself. I’11 be myself. Christine kisses him on the head, leaves.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You’re not gonna do that at school?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I promise. In the high chair, Katie crosses her arms.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: No banana.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Katie, you like banana. Remember? Mmmmm. Ba-nah-nah.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: No banana!

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Where’s my lunch?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: In the fridge. Would you... Mitch motions for Billy to help him. Grudgingly, Billy ta piece of Katie’s banana.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (deadpan) Mmm. Banana. Yum. Yum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banana! She’s beaming, overjoyed. Stuffs her face with banana. grabs a brown bag from the refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Nervous?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You lie. Come here. (kneeling) Your mom told you to be yourself, right? She’s smart. I love your mom. But. Better idea: Be funny.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Funny?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I went to six schools in eight years, and let me tell you, funny works.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Okay, I’1l do it. Thanks. Mitch points to a cheek. Billy gives him a peck.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You're a heartbreaker. Now get your butt to school. Billy takes off. Mitch stands tall, proud of his accomplishment. Cheeks puffed, Katie starts to WHINE. pitch climbs higher and higher, a bomb about to explode.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Katie, honey? (leans close) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Banana! 18. Billy The Mitch wipes a spray of banana and milk off his face. Kati beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe rides up, kicking the brakes to spray gravel. Billy a  19. wave away the dust. Joe points to the Cowlicked Kid.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That pole is mine. Go lock your Big Wheel somewhere else. The Cowlicked Kid moves his Huffy away. As he locks his b Joe checks out Billy’s bike. Billy stands tall. His bike doesn’t suck.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: So Forrester, why’d you move here?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You know. Scenery. That and the arrest record. The joke dies. Not even a smile.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: His mom is the new...OW! What? Billy just kicked him. Hard.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: So I heard this great joke. There’s these two guys and they’re hunting...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) No, I’m serious. Why did you move here? From behind them, Hicks comes racing up on rims.

dialogues.speaker: HICKS
dialogues.text: Guys! Guys! Check it out! TURN to see Suzie Saint-Claire walking her bike to the ra Kick into “Unchained Melody.” The boys stare in lust... Suzie’s face. Body. Bike. Spokes glimmering, reflectors flashing...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: That is the most beautiful bike I’ve ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: A Rockhopper 16J Elite™. (to Alan) Where’d your sister get that?  20.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No girl should own that bike. At the far end of the racks, Suzie finally notices the pa boys staring at her. It’s creepy.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: So anyway, there’s these two guys hunting... Suzie finishes locking up and leaves. Like moths to a fla the boys all move toward the bike, leaving Billy alone wi joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine unpacks books onto a shelf. Finishing one box, cuts open another with a giant utility knife, sweeping so that the blade sticks into her desk. She struggles to get free, her frustration increasing. God bless her, she’s about as coordinated as a drunken St Bracing with a foot for leverage, she tries to pull it lo Her shoulder bumps into the shelf. It falls. Twelve textb rain down on her, the final one beaning her on the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three LITTLE GIRLS in starched dresses carry bouquets of dandelions. They knock on Christine’s door, pushing it op

dialogues.speaker: THE GIRLS
dialogues.text: (singing) Hello hello and welcome welcome, welcome to our school. Back turned, eyes wide and maniacal, Christine yanks the with a mighty GRUNT. It pops free, spinning her to reveal guests. They SCREAM. One girl drops her dandelions. The other two Finally, the third follows. Christine makes it to the doo

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: (still reeling) Wait! Come back! Come ba-a-a-ack. She slumps back into her office, pressing her head agains door to squeeze out the pain. Her eyes are crossed.  21.

dialogues.speaker: A WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You must be Christine. Blurry at first, the WOMAN comes into focus.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I’m Eveylne Saint-Claire. I’m a “mom.” In your hair already.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: No, it’s... (dizzy) It’s great to meet you. Still dazed, she sets the knife down to shake hands. Mrs. Claire is a handsome woman with a Breck Girl smile and th emotional stability of an abused hummingbird.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I have two kids. Twins. Suzie and Alan. Both are what you’d call (“air quotes”) “special needs.” My daughter Suzie is very bright. She’s been tested. What’s a number, I know. It was 140. And because of her abilities, her peers sometimes have trouble relating to her. You understand. Jealousy. Christine nods. Mrs. Saint-Claire examines the struggling spider plant on Christine’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Alan, my son, has a diagnosed attention deficit disorder, and also a bit of, well...I don’t want to blame his teachers, or the curriculum, but frankly he needed a whole-language approach. This phonics concept, it didn’t “hook” him. A beat. When Mrs. Saint-Claire looks back up, we see tear hanging in her eyes. They came out of nowhere. Her voice cracks a little...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Second grade, we would be at the dinner table and he would start making random vowel sounds. “Daa daaa DOO DOO dee.” This would go on for hours on end. It was heartbreaking. Christine doesn’t know how to handle this weeping woman.  22.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: What grade are they in now?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Fifth.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: My son Billy is a fifth-grader. He’s in their class. Mrs. Saint-Claire smiles beatifically, now happy tears.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Then you understand. You know what I’m going through. She rips the last dead leaves off the plant and puts it o windowsill just so. With her back turned, Christine WINCE the still-intense head pain.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I need to tell you that there were some parents, well-meaning parents, who were worried that since your last job was at a school of mostly... (which word?) ..-urban children, you might somehow bring those types of problems problems with you. Drugs and gangs and crack. I told them what I’m going to tell you: I think kids are kids. And each one of them is a unique little problem to solve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine tries to find something to say, but Mrs. Saint- fills the silence.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: People ask me, other mothers ask me, Eveylne, how can you sacrifice so much of your time for your kids? Don’t you want to go shopping, to the movies, take a little time for yourself? Guess what? It’s not a sacrifice at all. My kids are my life. They are. And when they tell me, “Mom, you’re the best,” I say no, I’m not. I just have the best kids in the world, and that makes it so easy. Christine smiles.  23.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I’‘1ll go. I know you're busy. I just wanted to say, “Hi.”

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: It was good to meet you. They shake as Mrs. Saint-Claire leaves. Alone at last, Christine squeezes her temples. The pain is palpable.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (leaning back in) Christine. She jumps.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I just wanted to say, I think we’re going to be great friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids load up their desks, ripping school supplies out of packaging. Hicks launches an eraser off his ruler. Pegs G in the head. Alan glues his hand to the desk. Weezer points to a kid’s lame ass pad of paper.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Oooh. Little Brave. I got Big Chief. Joe holds up his. It’s immense.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Indian Warlord. Billy checks his paper. Generic. He hides it in his desk. GRETCHEN DeMARCO, a chubby girl with frightening orthodon takes a sheet of Suzie’s notebook paper, compares it to h

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: You’re using college-ruled? I’m still using wide-ruled.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: I‘1l1 loan you some. Their teacher, MISS OVERHOLSER, is a willowy spinster thr years past retirement.  24.

dialogues.speaker: MISS OVERHOLSER
dialogues.text: Class, we have a new student this year. Billy, would you introduce yourself?

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Bill-EEEEEE. He stands, bobbing as he talks, trying to look cool.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’m Billy. We moved here from Los Angeles because my dad used to run this coffee shop, but it went bankrupt because he says it was ahead of its time. So anyway, I have a joke. He has a captive audience. The reins of destiny are his.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: So these two really stupid guys are hunting and like, okay they have a dog, a hunting dog like a lab or a pointer. I don’t know. It doesn’t really matter. Anyway these birds keep flying over all day but the hunters aren’t getting any. So finally one guy says to the other guy...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Maybe we oughtta throw the dog higher. A beat. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Yeah. That’s what he said. Embarrassed, Billy takes his seat. Tom shakes his head sa

dialogues.speaker: MISS OVERHOLSER
dialogues.text: That’s a very funny joke, Billy. Thank you. Also, the rest of the class might not know that your mother, Mrs. Forrester, is our new principal. We see Billy’s world crumble in SLOW MOTION. He sinks low his chair as the class turns to look at him. Joe smirks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen minutes of freedom. Each area has its own crowd, clique. Billy moves through the swings and teeter-totters  25. None of the other kids make eye contact with him.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE BLACKTOP
dialogues.text: Billy stands at the edge of a basketball game. When a KID the ball back-court, he’s right beside Billy.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: We already got teams.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE JUNGLE GYM
dialogues.text: From her perch, Suzie Saint-Claire watches as Billy walks

dialogues.speaker: HICKS
dialogues.text: Maybe it ate poison. Like rat poison. We look up as six BOYS stand around a dead bird, poking i a stick. Billy squeezes his head in to look. After a beat other boys walk away.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE BENCHES
dialogues.text: Tom looks up from his baseball cards. Billy looks over. T goes back to his trading. From the softball diamond, Joe motions for Billy to come He’s hanging out with Alan and few of his cronies. As Bil approaches, Joe tosses a Coke can in the air. SMASHES it bat, launching it into left field. Hands the bat to Billy Billy kicks his feet in the dirt, getting his footing. VA ANGLES: The Girls. The Boys. All eyes are on him. Billy tosses up a can, swings. Misses by a mile. Joe LAUG The recess bell RINGS. Billy tosses up another can. Swing connects.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: That’s the bell. We gotta go in.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I didn’t hear anything.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Everybody’s going in.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh that’s right -- your mommy’s the principal. A beat as the playground empties. Joe and Billy hold thei  26. ground. Finally they start heading in. Joe tosses up a ro

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Watch this. He connects with a Babe Ruth swing. We RUSH with the rock hurtles toward the school. The windows. Billy closes his Alan grins maniacally as...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh sh--- ...it CRASHES through a window, glass TINKLING as it hits concrete. Billy stares in horror.

dialogues.speaker: BY THE SCHOOL
dialogues.text: Suzie leans back around the corner, out of sight. She saw whole thing. She holds for a moment, a moral quandary. INT. PRINCIPAL’S OFFICE - DAY Billy sits alone in dread. Overhead, a fluorescent light FLICKERS. The clock TICKS menacingly. He turns around a picture frame on Christine’s desk, a ph his family on a camping trip. Suddenly the frame falls do Grabbing for it, he knocks over a house plant. Dirt every He kicks it under a chair. Sets the plant down. It teeter over, crashing into a Snapple. He frantically tries to blot up the spill. Halfway into dabbing, he looks to see what papers he’s using. Attendan sheets. He sits back on the counter, trying to sort them out. His hits a switch. A red light turns on -- INT. BILLY’S CLASSROOM - DAY A SQUELCH comes over the intercom. Miss Overholser and th look up. INT. PRINCIPAL’S OFFICE - DAY Billy tries to wring the papers out into the trash.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: he sees his mom talking to someone in the hall. Desperate shoves the wet papers in a drawer. Leaps for his chair. Christine comes in with water and aspirin, closing the do  27. behind her. At the last minute, Billy flips the family pi right-side-up. He smiles nervously. She sits across from

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: I wasn't expecting to see you so soon. (takes aspirin) Honey, I know this is awkward. If it helps, pretend I’m not your mom; I’m just your principal.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’m not gonna narc on my friends. That’s like the prime directive. INT. BILLY’S CLASS - CONTINUOUS The class is still looking up at the intercom. Suzie come from the hall, takes her seat.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE, (ON INTERCOM)
dialogues.text: I know you think you’re protecting your friends, but you’re not. They need to learn to take responsibility for their actions. Because eventually it's going to catch up with them. Joe tries to look cool, but his eyes betray him. Alan loo over. INT. PRINCIPAL’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS The weight of Christine's gaze is crushing. Billy squirms

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (a whisper) I can't tell you. A KNOCK at the door. ANOTHER TEACHER pokes his head in.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: (whispers, points) Intercom. Christine finds the switch. Realizing it’s been on all th time, Billy’s heart drops three floors.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: It was Joe McGuire who broke the window.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: You’re sure?  28.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: A reliable source just told me. And believe me, I know the work.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: (to Billy; disappointed) Looks like you’re off the hook. INT. BILLY’S CLASSROOM - DAY The room is dark as the class watches a ‘70s Scholastic f strip.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Contrary to its name, the dung beetle thrives on a wide variety of plant and animal refuse. All eyes are on Billy as he moves through the light to fi seat. At the door, Christine talks to Miss Overholser.

dialogues.speaker: MISS OVERHOLSER
dialogues.text: Joe McGuire. Would you come up here, please? A stirring goes through the class. Joe glares over at Bil who motions “I didn’t do it.” As Joe goes up to the door, kids in class stare accusingly at Billy -- a sacred coven been broken. Tom shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class is quiet, heads bent over for silent reading. A sucks up a page from his book, blowing to turn it over. J comes in from the hall, walking tough. All eyes follow hi he takes his seat. After a beat, Weezer leans over.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: (whispering) So what happened?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You wouldn't believe me if I told you.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: Sure we would. A beat.  INT.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (leans close) It was like this... CHRISTINE’S OFFICE - DAY Shadowy BLACK AND WHITE, all intercuts and close-ups. isn’t Billyvision -- this is Joe telling a fabulous and elaborate lie.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: She said...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: We can do this easy, or we can do this hard. I know you broke the window. Light through a broken window. Rock breaks the glass. Hand throws rock. Joe's face as he throws. Christine sets the rock down on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Lots of accidents happen at school. Kids disappear without a trace. Especially troublemakers. An empty desk.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Listen to me, Joe. I've already got a milk carton with your name on it.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYGROUND
dialogues.text: By the balance beam, a crowd of KIDS listens with rapt to Joe’s story.

dialogues.speaker: DANDELION GIRL
dialogues.text: It’s true! She had a knife.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: What’d you say?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I stuck with my story. 29. This attention  30.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: You are so brave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One basketball-playing BOY leans over to ANOTHER.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: I heard if you even sneeze in the library, she makes you clean out the chalk trays. With your tongue.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THEM
dialogues.text: A PIG-TAILED GIRL swings one end of a jumprope. Suzie is sitting nearby, reading “The Fountainhead.”

dialogues.speaker: PIG-TAILED GIRL
dialogues.text: In California, because of the gangs, if you're tardy more than three times they cut off all your hair.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: No they don’t.

dialogues.speaker: PIG-TAILED GIRL
dialogues.text: It’s true. That’s why they wear bandanas. The JUMP-ROPING GIRL suddenly gets a panicked expression. Christine walks past, smiling. The pig-tailed girl finger precious hair worriedly.

dialogues.speaker: FURTHER ON
dialogues.text: Four LITTLE GIRLS are playing four-square when the ball t bad bounce. Christine catches the ball for them. The girl stare at her in wide-eyed horror. She smiles. Three of th girls back away in terror.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: (confused but comforting) Here you go. She tries to hand the ball to the remaining girl, who bre down in tears. Christine puts a hand on her shoulder to c her, but the girl runs away, SCREAMING. What did she do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd around Joe has grown to a mob, kids from every

dialogues.speaker: HICKS
dialogues.text: She was going to kill your dog?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That’s the only reason I gave in.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Man, that chick is mean.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: She’s not just mean. She’s some kind of supervillain.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: (decidedly) I hate her.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: at the edge of the crowd. Tom looks over to him. Billy sl away, trying to be invisible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy slides his tray down the slow-moving line -- it’s t day. A GIANT COOK with three missing fingers drops a new of crumbled meat into the steam table. Billy's up. The cook’s staring at him, a scoop of crumble meat ready.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Just milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s one of those long cafeteria tables where the sides f down into benches. Tom stands near the middle.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Peanut butter, peanut butter. Sold! Next I’ve got baloney on wheat, partly mushed. I see an apple, do I...fruit rollup! Going...Going...Sold! He makes the swap, giving the BALONEY KID his fruit rollu

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I get 10 percent of that.  32. Alan trades his entire lunch for sugar packets. He hordes like a junkie. Billy looks for a place to sit. Kids slide their trays to open gaps -- he’s being shut out. Billy takes a chair at short end of the table.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Move it, Forrester. That’s mine. Billy surrenders the chair, still no place to sit. Finall Suzie moves her tray to create an open space. Billy ends sitting in the middle of the girls’ section. It’s humilia

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: (low) Look at it this way. Your day can only get better.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe I could get hit by a truck. He looks through his lunch bag, but all that’s inside is styrofoam container.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Leftovers? Good market for that, especially Italian. Billy opens the lid to reveal...dirt.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: It’s just dirt.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What are you supposed to do? Grow your own?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Ch-Ch-Ch-Chia! Billy digs around in it, finally dumping it out on the tr squiggling pink mass of

dialogues.speaker: WORMS
dialogues.text: spills out. Real nightcrawlers, the kind that looks like have a band-aid around the middle. Girls SCREAM, everyone away. Billy looks at the container, confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fishing pole in hand, Mitch digs into a brown bag. Pulls sandwich. An apple. Cheetos. He knots his brow. Katie looks up from under a fishing ha With a shrug, Mitch threads a Cheeto on the hook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead quiet. Everything feels hyper-real, stylized. The cl stands back, staring at the pile of dirt. A few worms dro the side of the table, SMACKING on the floor below.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Hey Forrester. Dare you to eat one. Like spectators at a tennis match, all heads swivel to Bi

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: No way. (beat) I mean, you're kidding, right? WHIP PAN back to Joe...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You’re not just a snitch, you’re a wuss, too. Billy looks around at the other kids. Maybe Joe was serio The moment passes. En masse, the girls carry their trays to a new table, lea Billy behind. He starts to scoop the dirt and worms back the container.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: (low) God, he’s such a freak. When no one’s looking, Tom leaves Billy half his sandwich

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO SHOT: It’s down between Billy and the Cowlicked Kid.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Simmons. The Cowlicked Kid takes his place with the team. Billy, t humiliated leftover, goes with the others.  34.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Hut! Hut! Hike! As quarterback, Joe scans for an open receiver. Billy's covering his man tight. Finally, Joe makes a break for it Billy’s all over him, de-flagging him just before the goa

dialogues.speaker: COACH MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Nice hustle, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Thanks, Dad. Coming up behind Billy, Joe shoves him hard, sending him tumbling. No one saw him do it. Joe gives him a hand to help him up. Drops him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERIES OF SHOTS: Against a mottled-leaf background, Suzie strikes a Glamour pose. FLASH. Weezer can’t decide whether to smile with or without teet FLASH. Alan looks wholesome and decent. His eyes suddenly bug ou FLASH. Tom checks his look in a big mirror. Billy's behind him, to get the mud off his shirt. There’s a noticeable gap in line behind him.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Why does everyone treat me like I’m radioactive? Tom pulls him to face the mirror. In the reflection, Christine’s head is growing out of Billy’s shoulder. Billy spins to see Christine against the far wall talking another teacher. She waves to him. Billy cringes. Tom sits on the stool, a Hollywood smile. FLASH.  35.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (to photographer ) How about another for protection? Back in line, the Cowlicked Kid comes up behind Billy.

dialogues.speaker: COWLICKED KID
dialogues.text: So B-b-b-b-billy. D-d-do you like Anim- m-maniacs?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Leave me alone, you little turd. It was loud enough that everyone heard. And looked. Billy ignores the stares. The Cowlicked Kid would die right now, if will alone coul manage it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming off the stage, Billy heads down a few hidden steps of the darkness, a hand grabs him, pinning him against th It’s Suzie.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Leave Simmons alone.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean...OW!

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: You want to pick on somebody, pick on the kid on top. Don’t be a thug. With another shove, she leaves him in the shadows to reco school bell RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: End of the day. The class stacks their chairs on their de Billy tries to make eye contact with the Cowlicked Kid, b boy won’t look over. As people file out past Billy, it’s like he’s invisible. Suzie glares as she passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing near the building, Billy watches as Joe and the boys are unlock their bikes. Tom, Weezer, Hicks and Gelma a loose group along the edge of Joe’s pack. At the far en the bike racks, the Cowlicked Kid unlocks his Huffy. Joe says something to him. We don’t hear what it was, but hurt. Billy closes his eyes. Breathes twice. And walks. Joe's cronies nudge him as Billy approaches.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Hey Joe. You're on.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: On what?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’m taking your bet.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What bet?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’m gonna eat a worm. He unzips his pack and takes out the styrofoam container. is genuinely surprised. He hardly remembers the bet.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: And if I do it, Simmons gets to lock his bike there. He points to the Cowlicked Kid, who’s startled. “huh?” runs through the kids.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No way. It would take a crapload more than one worm.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Okay. Two worms. An “OOOH” goes through the boys.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: A hundred. Billy hesitates. Then... A general  37.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Five. Billy looks at Tom -- what the hell are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Fifty.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Seven.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Fifty-seven.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Wait! This isn’t at all what he planned. He looks around at the kids looking at him. For just this moment, he’s not a dor

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I‘1l eat as many worms as are in this pack. One a day, as long as it takes. All eyes on Joe. He looks at Billy, at the container.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys fingers sort through the dirt, picking out the worms try to squiggle back toward the clump.

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: ..-Eleven...Twelve... Billy looks in, surprised just how many there are.

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: ...Thirteen...Fourteen...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Fif...Is that really one worm?

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Jesus H. Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: HICKS
dialogues.text: It’s one piece. Maybe it’s a mutant. The WORM in question is easily three times the size of th Some  38. others, not just in length, but also girth.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: It’s Big Charley.

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: (agreeing) Big Charley.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (to Billy) I'd eat him last. Billy looks to Joe.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: A worm a day for fifteen days. Fixed however I want.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: And I have to see you eat it. Billy and Joe spit on their hands to cement the deal. Sha

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: One more thing. No snitching to Mommy. We keep this just between us. If anybody tells anybody anything, I will personally kick his ass. Everybody swear.

dialogues.speaker: ALL THE BOYS
dialogues.text: (loosely together) Swear.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: Where are you gonna eat the first one?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I know a place. He looks over to the school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An creaky old JANITOR wheels his mop bucket, starts a new section. He has his back turned, WHISTLING. Tom peers aro corner, signals the all-clear. Cue “MISSION IMPOSSIBLE”-type theme. A squad of a dozen B scurries down the hall, ducking for cover. Weezer sneaks the janitor. His sneakers SQUEAK on the wet floor. He fre  39. The janitor stops WHISTLING. Echoey quiet. From their hid places, the boys panic. Weezer moves to stay behind the j as he turns. He ducks safely into the cafeteria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SWOOP in on Billy, Joe, Alan and Hicks crouching behind a dumpster. Billy checks his Swatch. All four watch as the school cook opens a side door from the kitchen. He hangs apron on a hook, takes his motorcycle helmet. Billy motions to Gelman, hidden in the bushes. Gelman fla his glasses in the sunlight, sending a signal to...

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. SIDE WINDOW
dialogues.text: ...the Cowlicked Kid, who relays the message inside to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..+-Tom, who motions Go! Go! Go! Weezer holds open the cafeteria door as the boys sneak behind the Janitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cook checks his keys, locks the knob on the outside d Billy panics.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: C’mon Tom! The door is perilously close to shutting when --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom POUNDS on the inside door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the nick of time, the cook hears it. He steps back ins Billy and Hicks dash for the door before it closes. They strip of duct tape over the jam to keep it from locking.

dialogues.speaker: COWLICKED KID
dialogues.text: I didn’t fart. You farted.  40.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Smelt it, dealt it. Tom SHUSHES them. The top half of the kitchen door swings The cook looks out into the empty cafeteria. Huh. REVERSE to see Tom and the rest of the kids pressed back the wall. The cook shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy and Joe hide again. The cook comes out, lets the do shut. He heads across the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (to Alan) Stay here and keep watch.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to watch?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Everything. Billy, Joe and Gelman duck into the kitchen. Alan’s head swivels as he tries to watch everything at once. Two SECO GRADE GIRLS walk past, unnerved by Alan’s bug-eyed autism

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Hihowzitgoin’? The girls RUN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gelman opens a cabinet. Forty-seven pans fall out, CLANGI endlessly. Everyone SHUSHES everyone else. Weezer opens a refrigerator, helping himself to a few bow Jello. Billy is fiddling with the controls on the big sto

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: How do we turn this on?

dialogues.speaker: HICKS
dialogues.text: Try this one. A jet of flame shoots up in the background.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: It’s not doing anything.  41. The flame dies. No one saw it. Tom digs out a worm from t styrofoam pack.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: We gotta like kill it first. Y'know, eucharize it.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Whattawe gonna do, shoot it? Joe jams a spatula into a crack. Puts the worm on the end launches it like a catapult. It hits SMACK against a wall Hangs for a sec. Then falls. The boys lean in to look.

dialogues.speaker: HICKS
dialogues.text: Is it dead?

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: I think it’s dazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing at his Harley Softtail, the cook checks his pock Thinks for a second. Turns and heads back toward the scho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PUSH IN on a pair of sunglasses, forgotten on the desk Their eyes at grill-level, the boys drop a worm on the gr surface, where it SPUTTERS and POPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan, still frantically watching everything at once, fina spots the cook heading his way. He panics, yanking on the door. Locked. Nowhere to run. We CROSS-CUT back and forth, Alan and the approaching coo still hasn’t seen him. Alan finally leaps into the dumpst

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Go! Weezer and Hicks race to see who can SNARFLE up a bowl of first. Weezer wins.  42.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: (nose stuffed) Undofooted! He plugs a nostril and blows out chunks of lime-green sno boys stare at him in horror.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: What! It’s natural. Weezer realizes the boys are staring behind him. He turns face the stomach of the giant cook. He SCREAMS... And SCREAMS... Until he can’t scream any more. It’s very quiet, just the of the worm SIZZLING on the grill. Billy sets a pan over hide it. The cook looks around at the dozen boys in his kitchen, a mess they’ve made. Flour spills on the floor. A spatula f and CLANGS.

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: I’ve got a shotgun in that closet. It comes out in ten seconds. Nine seconds...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Go! Go! Gol! The boys scurry, setting things straight and heading for door. Billy grabs the fried worm in a napkin. Gelman and trip over each other. Weezer shoves half-snarfled Jello b the refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: Three. Two. One. Stuck in the doorway, Gelman, Hicks and Weezer pop throug kitchen is empty. EXT. SOMEBODY’S BACK YARD - DAY

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (low; to Tom) I can’t do it. I can’t. I'’11 hurl. He hands the napkin-wrapped worm back to Tom.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: If he hurls, it doesn’t count.  43.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Yeah! Alan peels off some of the trash stuck to his body. Licks popsicle wrapper. Tom pulls Billy aside.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: If you don’t do this, you’re gonna look like a double wuss and a backer-outer.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I know. I can do it, I just can’t think about doing it. I needa distraction. A beat. Tom suddenly KICKS him in the shin. Billy HOLLERS pain, jumping around on one leg.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (fed up) I’m out of here.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Wait! I’11 do it. We PUSH IN on Billy, who breathes in through his nose, ou through his mouth. Again. And again. And then... He eats it. It’s chewier than you'd think, tough and stri like jerky. The boys watch, fascinated, as he chews 15 ti and swallows. He licks the inside of his mouth to get rid the taste.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Doesn’t count unless it stays down. The kids lean a little closer, waiting to see if he’s goi choke or die or what. Billy looks around, unsure himself. His lower lip begins to tremble. His jaw. Then his whole His arms start to quake. Everyone takes a step back. Pre-hurling chest contractions.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: He’s gonna blow! Kids cram against the back wall, backs turned. Billy’s wh body begins to convulse, a standing seizure. An inhuman RETCHING sound. Then...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Psych!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He’s totally fine.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: I knew he was faking. (to Hicks) You believed him. Joe pries open Billy’s mouth, peers inside. Billy moves h tongue so the world can see. Nada.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: The worm has been eaten! Weezer and Gelman CHEER. On Joe’s glare, they suck it bac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch is at the seafood counter. Katie is in the cart, st wearing her dad’s fishing hat.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Hi. I’m looking for three fish of an impressive but not unrealistic size.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGER
dialogues.text: Like salmon?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Like salmon but not salmon. Think local. Do you have anything that could be caught here?

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGER
dialogues.text: We have a tank. Mitch looks down at the tank.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Okay. These are lobsters. Now, of the two words...”local”...”“fish”... Fish was far and away the more important. The TEENAGER smiles, confused and frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGER
dialogues.text: We have bluefish on special.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Is that local? A beat. The teenager shrugs, no idea.  45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch waits in line for the register when he spots Coach and Constable Jackson in the “10 Items or Less” lane. Aft beat, he steers his cart that direction. On the way, he sheds items out of his cart, winnowing it ten.

dialogues.speaker: IN LINE
dialogues.text: Mitch unloads his cart onto the belt. Three lobsters scur get away.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE JACKSON
dialogues.text: Mike.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (mock surprised) Oh, hey. Mitch, actually. The Coach and the Constable are buying beer. Katie tugs a Dad’s sleeve. He shushes her, not right now.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE JACKSON
dialogues.text: How are you settling in?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Great. Fine. Just, you know, everything's doing really good.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: I made yellow. Mitch pats her on the head, embarrassed. The Coach gets h change. He and the Constable are leaving when the Coach t

dialogues.speaker: COACH MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: So Mitch, we’re going to be drinking some beers on the boat later. Why don’t you come by?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I’ll be there. As the men leave, Mitch makes a tiny “woo-hoo.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men kick back with cigars and Heinekens. Stars the giant night sky. Constable Jackson SIGHS with satisfa Mitch makes an even bigger SIGH, so obvious that it’s fun  46.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: So Mitch. Doris says you used to run a coffee shop.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Actually, it was a copfee shop. Combination coffee shop and copy shop. You could get some mochaccino, run some resumes.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE JACKSON
dialogues.text: Did you have those biscotti things? Man, I love those.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Doris says you went bankrupt.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE JACKSON
dialogues.text: Thing is, it looks like toast, but really, it’s a cookie. BILLY’S VOICE (0.S.) Dad? Dad!

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Up here! He looks over the side of the boat. Instead of water, we grass. We’re in Coach McGuire’s back yard.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Mom says you’re supposed to come home. Mitch shrugs to his friends, starts climbing down. Coach McGuire cracks an invisible whip.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE OVER
dialogues.text: EXT. TOM’S BACK YARD - DAY Tom drops the worm into a coffee grinder. Puts the lid on WHIRS. He stops, but the BUZZING continues. It’s Alan. He keeps at it until everyone’s staring at him. Tom spreads the paté on a ritz. Billy stares at it. The p is pink and chunky.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: He won't do it.  47.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN / WEEZER / HICKS
dialogues.text: I wouldn't. / I would. / I might. Once.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Not twice.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: First time was a fluke. Billy’s still staring. He taps at it with the tip of his tongue.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Want me to kick you again?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I can do it. He psyches himself up for a monster chomp. At the last se loses his nerve. Leaning close, Tom tries a different tac

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Maybe you shouldn’t do it. Back out now, call the whole thing off. Who cares what everybody thinks? If people make fun of you, you can just sick your mom on them. She could have them in detention like that. I mean, yeah, people may hate you and fear you and not invite you to parties, but at least they’1l only be saying the really bad stuff behind your back. A beat. Billy inhales the cracker, chewing and swallowing quick. With a swig of water, he gets the crumbs down.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: The worm has been eaten! A few kids CLAP, but the applause dies as they look to Jo Still, Tom recognizes the subtle shift in perception.

dialogues.speaker: A GIRL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Whatcha doing? All heads spin back to the fence. Gretchen DeMarco is nur pudding pop, watching the whole thing.  48.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Doesn’t look like nothing. Looks like he just ate a worm. How come he did that? The boys look at each other. The girl knows too much.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Scatter! The boys run off in a hundred different directions. Gretc stays put with her pudding pop, perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy and Gelman join up with Tom and Hicks, who are hidi

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We gotta plan this better. If girls find out about this, they’1l tell their moms and their mom’s will tell his mom. From now on, we follow strict security protocols.

dialogues.speaker: HICKS
dialogues.text: All information on a need-to-know basis.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: HICKS
dialogues.text: You don’t need to know.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE OVER
dialogues.text: EXT. TOM’S HOUSE - DAY Binoculars around his neck, Hicks watches as SOME GIRLS w past. When they’re out of range, he talks into a walkie-t he was hiding.

dialogues.speaker: HICKS
dialogues.text: Perimeter is clear. Repeat. Perimeter is clear. INT. TOM’S KITCHEN - DAY  49. On cue, boys pull down all the window shades. Lock all th doors. Tom opens the toaster over to reveal a crisp worm dangling in the grill. A wavy pink french fry. Dipping it in ketchup, Billy eats it in three bites.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER JACKSON
dialogues.text: Thomas? She pushes open the door from the dining room. There are dozen boys in her kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We were just, uh, cleaning. Everybody but Joe grabs something and starts scrubbing, scraping, moving things around. Alan eats a big squeeze o pancake syrup. Tom smiles wholesomely.

dialogues.speaker: INT. A DARK PLACE
dialogues.text: A shaft of light. A worm SWIRLS in a tornado. By flashlight, the boys are crammed around a hot-air popc popper. Alan looks especially evil with the light under h chin. Joe shoves somebody’s elbow out of the way. Tom dum the worm out. It’s hardened like a pretzel. EXT. SOMEBODY’S LAWN - DAY Suzie and some other GIRLS stand with their bikes, watchi duct-taped refrigerator box lying on its side. Billy brea seal, stepping out into the blinding light. The other boy follow, like circus clowns-in-a-car. Seeing the girls, th to play it cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An electric cord is plugged into a wall socket. We RACE A series of extension cords, plugged end-to-end, following under tables...around chairs...over sleeping dogs...out a window... OUTSIDE... .»+-across a patio...through the grass...into a pond... underwater...back on the grass...up a tree...in through a window...  50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...to a waffle iron. Tom drops a worm on the ridges, squi the iron closed. There are fifteen boys crowded in the tiny treehouse, all talking at once. Hicks opens the trapdoor to let in three

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Hurry it up. I don’t got time for this buttsqueeze. The light on the waffle iron blinks out.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We're ready. Tom opens the iron to reveal a crinkle-cut worm. All the crowd around close to get the best view. Billy reaches fo Coke, but it

dialogues.speaker: ROLLS
dialogues.text: away from him, finally hitting the wall.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Guys. Guys! Shut up! Shut up! Everyone shuts up. We hear a CREAKING and a GROANING, woo pulling apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The treehouse is canted at an angle, all the weight on on It’s perilously close to falling.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Nobody move. Nobody moves. Nobody breathes. The CREAKING stops. A tiny bird flutters in, landing on the windowsill. The treehouse starts CREAKING again. The boys SCREAM... The trapdoor opens. Weezer climbs in, takes a seat. The treehouse leans back to normal.  51.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: What did I miss? Did I miss it? What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the boys head their own directions, Tom calls out afte

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hey Joe. What are you gonna do if he makes it?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I didn’t bet that he couldn’t eat five worms. I bet that he couldn’t eat fifteen. There’s an ominous quality to the statement that eludes n

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A swarm of PARENTS crowds the hallways. Christine does th and-greet at the door. Mitch carries a sleeping Katie. As her husband videotapes everything, Mrs. Saint-Claire c the student artwork hung on the walls. She exhales sharpl shocked.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: This is Suzie’s! Buried below eye level. Mr. Saint-Claire grunts that he hears her, busy recording something else.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Cover me. She moves Suzie’s into a better location. The bell RINGS. INT. BILLY’S CLASSROOM - NIGHT In the back of the class, Mitch and the other dads sit in respective sons’ desks, knees wedged in tight.

dialogues.speaker: MISS OVERHOLSER
dialogues.text: In our American History unit, we’ll start by looking at the seeds of democracy... While Miss Overholser has her back turned, Coach McGuire  52. deadarms Constable Jackson. Jackson overshoots with a spi pegging Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: (fake cough) Loser.

dialogues.speaker: MISS OVERHOLSER
dialogues.text: ...and of course, the American Revolution. The Coach launches an eraser. Mitch reaches his arm out, stretching. Knocks off the Coach’s hat. Some of the other PARENTS are watching the horseplay. Mitch tilts back in h chair to dodge a spitball. It hits Mr. Saint-Claire right the camcorder.

dialogues.speaker: MISS OVERHOLSER
dialogues.text: Boys! Mitch’s chair tips out from under him. He CRASHES back.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Ow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the podium, Christine finishes a conversation with Tom Grandmother. A crowd of other PARENTS wait to introduce themselves. Next is Mrs. Saint-Claire.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Hi, friend!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Evelyne. Mrs. Saint-Claire hands over a tin of cookies.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: It’s a modified Tollhouse. I use Peruvian chocolate with fresh vanilla. I find fresh vanilla makes all the difference.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Thank you, that’s so sweet.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: What you said about letting kids be kids, I couldn’t agree with you more. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE (cont'd) I’m not one of those “hover mothers” who dictates every aspect of their children’s lives.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: I think that’s very important. Another MOTHER tries to reach in and say hello to Christi Mrs. Saint-Claire turns and snaps viciously...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I am talking to her now. If you want to talk to her, you can wait. I waited. The MOTHER backs off.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (to Christine, eyes rolling) Some people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching TV, Alan eats powdered Tang by the spoonful. Joe ripping pages out of a half-dozen books. Suzie stands in doorway.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Mom says you’re not supposed to eat in here.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Go eat your butt. Exasperated, Suzie pulls out a Polaroid camera -- FLASH. is blinded.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: (re: photo) I’m adding this to the collection. She exits. He throws a magazine after her, knocking over lamp. Suzie leans back in to document the destruction. FL

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Check this out. He hands Alan pages ripped from a medical guide, includin anatomy transparencies.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Naked people.  54. Joe switches the pages.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (reading) Cronerary ringworm is a result of ingesting worm larvy... (figures out) Hey Joe. This is from the dog book. Joe takes the page back, rips off the header.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Not any more. Gimme some tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV BLARING, Billy sits with his head tilted. REVERSE to see the entertainment center, still slanting 3 the right. On screen, the David Lynch epic DUNE, the part Kyle McLachlan rides the giant worms. The doorbell RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy flips through a stack of taped-together pages. Joe Alan stand on the doorstep.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: We wouldn’t have told you if it wasn’t gonna, like, kill you.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: It’s fetal.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Why are these all taped together?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: We wanted to be really complete.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Why does it say “canine”? Joe looks at the word.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That’s “kuh-neen.” Means it’s gonna kill you.  55.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: It’s fetal. Billy hands them back the papers, starts to shut the door

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Hey! If worms are safe, how come they don’t sell ‘em at the supermarket? How come dogs get sick when they eat ‘em? I‘1l tell you why. Because they’re poison. Billy shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: They’re fetal.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Billy leans back against the door. It’s not that he belie them. But what if what they’re saying is a little true? INT. BILLY’S ROOM - NIGHT It’s very late. A shaft of light from the street falls ac Billy as he lies awake in bed, hands on his stomach. As h closes his eyes, a GURLGING and RUSHING begins. Something his gut is moving. His eyes snap back open. He feels his stomach. What’s goi in there?

dialogues.speaker: TITLE OVER
dialogues.text: A WORM with an accordion leans into the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: THE WORM
dialogues.text: Ever-ee-bahdy polka! As the WORM BAND gets into it, we REVERSE to see the danc floor. WORM COUPLES dance and spin like only invertebrate One couple spins too fast, causing the gentleman to rip i Both pieces get up and start dancing with each other. We around until we get woozy, finally cutting to... INT. MITCH AND CHRISTINE’S ROOM - NIGHT The alarm clock reads 3:15 a.m. The door suddenly BLASTS  56. Lights FLARE.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Mom! Dad! Wake up! Wakeupwakeupwakeup! They're not moving fast enough, so he starts JUMPING up a on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Earthquake! Katie! He trips as he climbs out of bed, falling on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Billy, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I ate a...I ate... He wants to tell, but he can’t.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I ate a bug. Christine and Mitch sit there, breathless and dazed. What

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch and Billy flop on the couch while Christine talks o phone in the background. She calls out...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Billy, what time did you eat it?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: About 3:30. Christine relays the information over the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: So this was a one-time thing, right? Some kind of dare.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (very seriously) I can’t tell you.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I knew it. Secret society stuff. In college once I had to eat three live goldfish.  57.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I guess they were goldfish. I dunno. I was blindfolded.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Cool. Christine hangs up and comes over.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: I called Dr. McGrath in California. She said if you’re feeling okay now then not to worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: So I’m not gonna die?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Told ya. Billy is relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch and Christine climb back into bed.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: I blame you. She switches off the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a thumbtack, Tom is frantically trying to pin someth down. It’s an earthworm. He pins it back to the cardboard He and Billy are lab partners for worm-dissection. Nearby Suzie and Gretchen, Joe and Alan.

dialogues.speaker: MISS OVERHOLSER
dialogues.text: Next we’re going to bisect the worm along the axis. Mistaking it for the chalk, she SCRAPES the scalpel acros chalkboard. The class SCREAMS. With a sudden CHOP, Joe ha his worm in half.  58.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Hey Alan. We got a bisexual worm. Billy and Tom look into their open worm, its skin pinned It’s not a pretty picture.

dialogues.speaker: MISS OVERHOLSER
dialogues.text: You’1l notice the digestive system of the worm is essentially a tube. Dirt and food matter enters through one orifice, is processed and digested by enzymes, then is expelled as waste matter through the other orifice.

dialogues.speaker: HICKS
dialogues.text: Wazzat mean?

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: It’s crap.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (leaning over) Hey Forrester. Hungry? Billy ignores him. Nauseous, he picks at something with t blade.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (to Tom) Is that dirt?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t know which end’s which. The other boys huddle close, staring.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Hey Forrester. You are what you eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hicks is propped up over the edge, scanning the horizon w binoculars. The largest group of kids yet is gathered at bottom of the ravine to watch the worm-eating. Billy is p and sweating. Tom is fanning him. Joe smirks to himself.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I can’t do it.  59.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What do you mean? It’s a s’more. It is a s’more. Tom pokes the worm back into the melted marshmallow.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What if it’s, y'know, working on something. Tom turns the s’more 180 degrees.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: See, now it’s just the dirt side.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Either way, you gotta eat the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hey Joe. Read between the lines. He holds up three fingers. Half-convinced, Billy takes th s'more. He bites into it. The worm pulls out, caked with chocolate and marshmallow goo. He sucks it in and swallow The boys CHEER. Joe walks away, kicking a rock into low o Billy looks woozy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine SCRAPES at the charred interior. Mitch leans in look. He stares at the cookie he’s eating.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Huh. The fresh vanilla really does make a difference.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Don’t eat those. They’re poison.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: They’re great.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: They’re made with evil intent. That woman is Donna Reed with a deathwish. (beat) Has Billy been acting weird around you?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Weird funny? Weird droopy? Weird eek- a-eek-a-eek?  60. He makes Psycho-stabbing motions.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: I dunno. Like something's up.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
