dialogues.text: I’1l have a little talk with him. Father to son, guy to guy. (re: cookie) No woman who bakes this well can be all evil. Christine takes his cookie away. Eats it. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: See?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: No. I hate her more. INT. BILLY’S ROOM - NIGHT Billy is sitting on his bed, counting the worms left in t styrofoam container. A KNOCK at the door. Billy hides his stash behind him.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (leaning in) Sport. Is anything up? Are you acting weird?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Okay. Just checking. Mitch walks away. Billy hides the container in a Igloo co under his bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A doorbell RINGS. Miss Overholser looks up from the spell tests she’s grading. It’s much too late for guests.

dialogues.speaker: FOYER / AT THE DOOR
dialogues.text: Stepping back from the peephole, she opens the door to re

dialogues.speaker: MISS OVERHOLSER
dialogues.text: Cyrus McKewin. It’s after nine!  61. CYRUS is a Scottish gentleman of 83 years. He looks up to tears in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MISS OVERHOLSER
dialogues.text: Oh Cyrus, it’s not your mother?

dialogues.speaker: CYRUS
dialogues.text: She’s dead Kate, just this evening. The angels came at four past eight. A respectful beat. Then suddenly...

dialogues.speaker: CYRUS
dialogues.text: Marry me, Kate. Elope with me tonight. We'll see the sun come up in Paris and set in Rome.

dialogues.speaker: MISS OVERHOLSER
dialogues.text: Cyrus... Tears fill her eyes. She flees into the next room, out of sight. Cyrus is heartbroken.

dialogues.speaker: CYRUS
dialogues.text: Surely there can be no one left to raise eye at us, to give reason we cannot wed. Our love buried them all. (realizing; crestfallen) Unless you don’t believe a Catholic and a Luteran can have any hope together. Miss Overholser returns. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MISS OVERHOLSER
dialogues.text: I was getting my coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A jet takes off overhead, leaving only the black night sk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SWEEP PAST the empty blackboard to reveal the fifth-gr most in their seats, a few pacing. Joe bounces a ball aga the closets. Billy checks his watch, then the clock. There’s no substitute. No adult at all.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: What if she’s dead?  62.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: If she’s dead, they would send a substitute.

dialogues.speaker: HICKS
dialogues.text: What if she’s dead and nobody knows she’s dead?

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: What if she’s fallen and can’t get up?

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: She's probably just sick.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Maybe the substitute got lost.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: Maybe the substitute is dead. Weezer gestures, “good point.”

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: We have to tell somebody that there’s no teacher.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Like who?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Like Billy’s mom. All eyes go to Billy. He’s not touching it. We look past to Gelman...

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: What if Billy’s mom killed them both?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: We don’t have to tell anybody anything. We're just going to sit here until something happens. He says it with a certainty that shuts everyone up. Every except Gretchen.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: What does Billy think?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Who cares what Billy thinks?  63.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Who cares.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’m cool with just hanging out, I guess. Joe gestures, “see?”

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: We should vote. We should vote on whether we’re going to tell anybody or not. (off boys’ groans) It’s the right thing to do.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: All in favor of not voting, raise your hand. All the boys raise their hands. They outnumber the girls. Suzie gives up, disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Maybe Joe’s right. As long as we don’t screw around, nobody's going to know the teacher’s not here. We just have to play it cool.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE OVER BLACK
dialogues.text: A volley of spitballs rains down as Weezer and Hicks wres the aisle, knocking over desks as they go. The Cowlicked barely avoids getting crushed.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Go long! From across the room, Joe passes the football to Alan, wh paying any attention. The ball knocks down a hanging fern everywhere. The girls wince, standing up on their chairs, out of the In its cage, the hamster runs frantically on his exercise Gelman opens the bottom drawer of the teacher’s desk. It’ the Ark of the Covenant.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: It’s all here.  64. Fourteen hands reach in to pull out 40 years of contraban dart guns, pocket knives, comic books. Tom tears a piece of paper, hands half to Billy. They eac off strips for spitballs, stocking up. With a Sumo stomp, Weezer braces for Hicks’ next charge. behind the desk, a volley of suction darts flies past.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Stop it. Stop it! For just a moment, quiet.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: We are in the fifth grade. We should be able to behave like grown ups for a few... An eraser TAGS her, leaving a blotch of chalk. She seethe keeps her cool.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: All I’m saying is that if we just work together, we can... She's hit by another eraser. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: You are so dead. She picks up both erasers and whips them back. The girls this as their cue to seek cover. They end up on the far s the room, away from the door.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE SINK
dialogues.text: Weezer cups his hand and turns on the pressure, shooting of water across the room.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THE CABINET
dialogues.text: Girls SCREAM, covering themselves. Some start throwing bo from the shelf in self-defense.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THE TEACHERS DESK
dialogues.text: Billy gets hit in the face by a book.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: One, two, three! Weezer leads a charge. Billy doesn’t follow him, his nose starting to bleed. Joe stays behind as well, a contented  65. on his face. Pencils and paperclips tumble off the desk. In SLOW MOTION, Weezer and company set upon the girls, st of Elmer’s glue hanging heavy in the air. Glitter grenade burst like fireworks, covering everything with sparkles. The Cowlicked Kid launches a frisbee that ricochets once, before WHACKING the sprinkler head in the middle of the c A drip of water. Another. And then a flood. An alarm RINGS as the rain begins. At first, everyone tri get out of the way, but the spray is inescapable. Suzie g her feet, soaked. Billy stands up from behind the desk. T trade a look of horror and resignation. For a moment, everyone stands where they are in the rain, paralyzed by impending doom. We PUSH IN on the sprinkler as it slows to a drip. We are now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The students stand in formation by the closets, still wet dripping.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: (to Gelman; low) Do I got glitter on my tongue? We slowly REVERSE to see that the room is destroyed. Smea paint soak into the carpet. Wet construction paper dangle the bulletin boards. Along with the JANITOR, Christine upends desks, dumping o water. She shakes out a textbook, but it comes apart in h hands. The kids keep their eyes low in shame and terror as Chris approaches. All but Billy, who has his head back to keep nose from bleeding. Christine takes a look.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Go down to the nurse’s office.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I think it’s almost...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Now.  66. There’s an edge to her voice that is best not questioned. Billy leaves, all the kids watch him. Watch her. INT. NURSE’S OFFICE - DAY Billy walks in with this head tipped back, trying to keep dripping.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Hi, is somebiddy here? I gotta bleddy nose.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Take a seat. BILLY’S P.O.V. We TILT DOWN from the ceiling to reveal the seven-fingere School Cook.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I thought you were the cook.

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: I also teach modern dance on Tuesdays. Sit. Billy complies. The Cook pokes his nose, making sure noth broken. He shoves cotton plugs up each nostril.

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: So how many worms have you eaten? (off reaction) I saw the worm. You’re not spilling anything, if that’s what you’re worried about.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (finally) Six. I have nine left.

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: Fifteen worms. Highest I ever heard somebody going was twelve.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Other people have done it?

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: They've tried.  He hands 67.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What happened to ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: Mostly they figured out how stupid it was to eat worms. Billy an ice pack.

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: What do you get if you win?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: No bike? No cash? Billy shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: So you’re doing it for honor. That's good. Only people who ever finished, finished for honor. They had a code.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What’s a code?

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: A code, it’s like...well. You know the difference between what’s right and what’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: See, a code helps you figure that out. It’s like a set of rules. When you get confused, you can just go back to your code. Me, I started with twelve things. Most of them probably don’t apply to you. Billy nods as he thinks it over. It makes a lot of sense. Heading for the door, he turns...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What’s my code?

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: That’s just it. You have to find it for yourself. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COOK (cont'd) (beat) But I‘1l get you started. Billy takes his seat again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine rescues the hamster from a pool of floating ced chips, moving it to higher ground. In the background, we Mrs. Saint-Claire in the doorway, in full panic mode.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Christine, are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: (wincing) I’m fine. Everything’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I just now heard about the crisis. Riot. Uprising. (gasp; pointing to carpet) Is that blood?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: It’s paint. Really, Evelyne. Everything is under control.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to alarm you on your first day, but I think there’s lead in the water. I do.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: There’s no lead. There’s just a lot of water. She scoops an eraser out of a puddle. Mrs. Saint-Claire s pretending to be calmer than she is.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I could form a committee.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Not necessary.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: We could have a bake sale to rebuild the classroom.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: A raffle.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: No! She didn’t mean to yell. It slipped.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I see. I see. I’m clearly out of my league. It’s only my kids we're talking about. Christine has the opportunity to jump back in. She passes MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE (CONT’D) You're the principal and I’m just a mom. I guess friendship is only for sunny days. With that she leaves. After a beat, Christine stifles a s chucking the eraser at the door. She feels guilty, but be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming in the door, an exhausted Christine scoops up an overjoyed Katie. She’s startled to see Billy waiting for the staircase.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I want to make amends.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Make amends?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I took an inventory.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Okay. (confused) Your dad and I were going to do this later, but we can do it now. Mitch! He looks in from the living room. She waves him in.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about trashing the room although I only did a little bit, a tiny bit really. But I’m sorry. That’s it. He’s done.  He nods. PPPPHEWWWW! Right over his head. She looks to Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: On a bigger picture, do you understand that you should have come to get me right at the start?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: And are you apologizing for that, too?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Why do I hafta apologize for something I didn’t do?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Didn’t do, but should have done.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’m not the only one who didn’t do it. We sorta voted. (to Mitch) If I’d have gotten her, I woulda been a dork.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: He’s right.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Sometimes doing the right thing means being a dork.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: She's right.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I guess I’m sorry then. I mean, if you want me to be. He climbs the stairs. Mitch has goosebumps.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Oooh. Parenting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: frosting, reading “Vote Suzie.” 70. A pastry tip lays out the last perfect ribbon of of forty flawless cupcakes. PULL BACK to reveal this is one  71.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: It just doesn’t seem...I don’t know. Fair.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, if life were fair, none of this would be necessary. People would recognize what a beautiful and talented young woman you are without any bias or false prejudice. But it’s nota perfect world, honey. I try to hide it from you guys, but I think you can see right through me. Here comes the tears. Suzie cringes to have made her moth once again.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: So if sometimes I do too much, just remember that I’m doing it all for you. If loving my kids is a crime, then lock me up. Lock me up. Suzie pats her mother’s back as she sobs.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (beat) You do want to be class president again, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Then you have to do whatever it takes to win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coach McGuire powers past Joe for a lay-up. Joe takes the back-court. Makes his charge. His father is all over him, blocking every move. He finally shoots. The ball reflects the backboard.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: You're not fighting for it. Defend your space. Here, cover me tight. Joe clings to his father. A quick pivot and Coach McGuire knocks him over, ass on the asphalt. The coach makes his  72.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That’s a penalty.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Maybe. If there was a referee. (helps him up) ) Sometimes you gotta take the foul. That’s not cheating. It’s part of playing aggressively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still damp, but vastly improved. The kids file in to see Christine at the blackboard. They keep quiet, eyes low. Finally, Weezer raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Where’s the substitute?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: You're looking at her. A collective GASP. Gelman MOANS. Billy slinks back in his seat, numb with shock.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: We've heard from Miss Overholser, and she'll be back in a week. Until then, I will be teaching your class in the mornings, Coach McGuire will teach in the afternoons. Any questions? A beat. Gretchen raises her hand.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: On behalf of the class, I just want to say welcome. The boys GROAN.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Christine walks down the aisle as they work in their work When she leans over to help the Cowlicked Kid, Joe smirks Billy.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: At the board, Christine asks a question. Only one hand go - the Cowlicked Kid. She picks Weezer instead. He glares Billy.  73.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Christine holds the trash can over to Gretchen, who spits her gum.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Coach McGuire is at the board, trying to figure out a mat problem. Suzie and Gretchen help him out.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Gelman falls into the aisle, reaching for the cupcakes Su handing out. Coach McGuire is telling a story. By its gestures, must be about football.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The end-of-day BELL rings. Kids rush to stack their chair The classroom is still damp, but vastly improved.

dialogues.speaker: PIG-TAILED GIRL
dialogues.text: Coach McGuire! The nominations?

dialogues.speaker: COACH MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Missy.

dialogues.speaker: PIG-TAILED GIRL
dialogues.text: Megan.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Take a seat everyone! The kids reluctantly sit back down, feet aimed for the do

dialogues.speaker: COACH MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: You’re supposed to nominate a candidate for class president. Suzie signals the Pig-Tailed Girl.

dialogues.speaker: PIG-TAILED GIRL
dialogues.text: I nominate Suzie Saint-Claire.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: You accept?

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Any other nominations? Suzie and the Pig-Tailed Girl smile at each other. Then,  74. last second...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Billy Forrester. All the boys turn. What the hell is Joe doing?

dialogues.speaker: COACH MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Billy, do you accept? Billy is caught off-guard. He looks around to Tom, Weezer the rest of the boys. They’re nodding. The Cowlicked Kid him the thumbs-up. It would inflate anyone's ego.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Why the hell not. (off his reaction) I mean, yes. The boys CHEER. Pig-Tailed Girl glances over to Suzie, panicked. But Suzie’s cool as an iceberg.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Alright, then. Elections are next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys rally around Billy by the bike racks. The attent starting to get to him -- the smile is getting a little s Tom hangs back a bit, forgotten. Suzie stands near.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You'll never take him. He’s too popular. ANGLE ON Suzie. She knows it’s true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We look through a knothole.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Spartacus, Rhombus, Barnaby Jones. Barney is dead, we're eating his bones. A gate opens and Weezer steps through. The gate shuts rig Tom gets to it. He KNOCKS.  75.

dialogues.speaker: HICKS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’s the password?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s me.

dialogues.speaker: HICKS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I know, but what’s the password? Tom gives his best cop-show kick to the gate. It blows op EXT. SOMEBODY’S BACK YARD - DAY A canvas screen is set up, creating a “back stage” area. other side, a crowd of BOYS is gathered to watch the worm eating. Billy sneaks up behind Tom. SHOUTS in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (startled) You’re here. You're late. Weezer peeks around the side of the screen.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Billy my man. Eating the worm! They swap high-fives. The boys on the other side start up CHEER: Bill-EE! Bill-EE!

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: We on for Deathcrusher later?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You got it. Weezer goes back around.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I thought we were on for Deathcrusher.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: He’s got Deathcrusher 2. The blood flies at you in 3-D.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s just, I thought we were going to hang out.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: We are. Later. (beat) A lot of people want to be my friends. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY (cont'd) It’s not fair if I just hang out with you. Tom is hurt and bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: A week ago everyone thought you were a dork. I was the only one who would hang out with you.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’m the one eating worms, not you. You're just sorta hanging on. You're one of those things that, you know, hangs on to other things. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Not anymore. (walking away) They were wrong. You’re not a dork. You’re an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Fine. Guess we’re not friends anymore.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Fine!

dialogues.speaker: FINE
dialogues.text: Billy walks around the blind, raising a CHEER from the ga kids. We watch Billy’s silhouette as he eats his worm. An CHEER. We see the first chink in Tom’s armor. He wipes aw angry tear before it really forms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys crowd around Billy at the middle of the table, l Joe and Alan by themselves. Thus the cool end isn’t so co

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I got PB and marshmallow. Skippy and fluffy together again. No one’s paying attention. They’re all wrapped up in a st Billy’s telling. By the hand motions, it seems to involve  77. machine gun. Tom hands the Cowlicked Kid back his sandwic Suzie looks at Tom, then at Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming out of the lunchroom, Billy and his admirers brush Christine. Billy doesn’t even look up at her. We stay on Christine, nonplussed. Further down the hall, whispers something to Weezer, who snickers. Christine hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy is picking his team. We PAN ALONG a line of boys, stopping on Tom.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Hicks. PAN OVER one more to reveal Hicks, who joins the team.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Jackson. Tom goes over to Joe’s team. Trades a glare with Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snap. As quarterback, Joe scans for an open receiver. Pas aiming for Tom. Billy plucks it out of the air, an interception. Tom tries to de-flag him, but Billy evades. Only Joe stands between him and the end zone. A little sh A little jive. Billy gets around him. Touchdown. Billy’s team goes nuts, CHEERING, high fives all around. watches from the distance.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Nicely done, Mr. Forrester. ANGLE ON Joe, betrayed. Billy brushes past him, cocky. Jo seething.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Saint-Claire throws pine cones at squirrels, trying t videotape their falls. Leaning off the porch, Alan and Jo flood the dirt with a hose.  78.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I dunno. I don’t see any worms.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You gotta look closer. (beat) Hey, Mr. Saint-Claire! Watch this! Joe pushes Alan off the deck, SPLAT into the mud.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: In the instant-replay, the boys’ heads are chopped off by framing.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Alan, go change so he can do that again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Alan changes clothes, Joe looks into Suzie’s room. making election posters on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: What do you want? He shrugs, nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I was just thinking.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: I thought I smelled something.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: We have a common enemy. After a beat, she looks up from her markers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy opens the door to reveal Suzie.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: My parents and I are going to a baseball game in the city tomorrow. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUZIE (cont'd) Alan isn’t coming, so I was wondering if maybe you’d like to come along. Unless, like, you and Tom have plans.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Tom and me aren’t friends anymore.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Oh. So do you wanna come?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Perfect. MUSIC rises as we kick into a zoomy, upbeat production nu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy rolls down his window, getting his first glimpse of East Coast city. A truck BELCHES exhaust into his face. S LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Range Rover crosses a gargantuan bridge, heading into Metropolis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie and her mom tip their heads to admire an amazing pa Billy plays with a really cool drinking fountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie sprays Billy with a perfume tester. He gets her bac erupts into warfare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd parts as Billy and Suzie find a place to stand. nearby HOMELESS GUY chokes on their scent, waving a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking alongside a goofy TEAM MASCOT, Mr. Saint-Claire t trip it, getting the whole thing on videotape. The giant does a “you wanna piece of me?” It shoves Mr. Saint-Clair

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Saint-Claire glares as someone drops peanuts on her.  80. and Suzie try to start a wave. No one follows along, whic even better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie stands in a long line, bouncing to hold it in. Bill waves her over to the men's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy stands guard outside a stall, trying to look casual tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy and Suzie snap at each other with fish heads on the fingers. Mrs. Saint-Claire gives them each a handi-wipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy throws a baseball, missing a stack of bottles. Suzi throws and nails them. Again. Again. And again. Billy is humiliated but impressed. For her prize, Suzie picks a wind-up monkey with cymbals. it to Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is exhausted. Everyone except Suzie.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Pleeeeease? Can't we stay just a little longer?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: It’s already 10 o’clock.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: (oddly desperate) Just another half hour. Her dad opens the car door, motions for her to plant some

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy is out for the count. He falls over onto Suzie’s shoulder. Suzie is wide awake, angst-ridden. She checks h watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy gives Christine a kiss as he trudges up the stairs. sheds clothes on his ascent. INT. BILLY’S BEDROOM - NIGHT He switches off the light, climbs into bed. The clock rea 11:48. A beat. He bolts straight up in bed.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: The worm! He digs the cooler out from under the bed, opening it to pool of icy water and no container. The worms are gone. EXT. TOM’S HOUSE - NIGHT Still in his pajamas, Billy BANGS on a window. TITLE OVER: 11:51 p.m.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Tom!

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Down here! Billy was banging on the wrong window altogether.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What’s wrong? Feeling guilty?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I forgot to eat my worm, and now they’re gone. I only got eight minutes left!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: SPRINKLERS rise in the night. Billy and Tom scan the lawn flashlights, soaked to the bone. TITLE OVER: 11:55 p.m.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Got one! Bring the others!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy races in through an unlocked back door.  82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a SINGLE SHOT, we follow Billy as he runs through the kitchen, the dining room, and the living room. At the foo the stairs, we hear a cat SQUEAL, its tail stomped. Billy the steps two at a time. On the second floor, Billy checks the doors. No. No. Yes! big Star Trek poster. He bursts in, flicking on the light

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Gelman! Wake up! Emergency! He shakes him. Gelman SCREAMS. He fumbles for his glasses the nightstand. They fall under the bed. GELMAN’S P.O.V. (way out of focus)

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: It’s Billy. Follow me! He runs out of the room. Gelman hurries after him, SLAMMI into the door frame. He feels his way along the wall. INT. TOM’S KITCHEN - NIGHT Tom throws the worm in the microwave, where it sticks aga the far side. SLAMS the door. Cranks it. The worm peels o the back, slowly inflating to 10 times its normal size.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The back door is locked. Racing alongside the house, Bill spots an open window.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Give me a boost. The blind Gelman is no help at all, always facing the wro direction. Finally Billy forces Gelman up against the wal over the windowsill. He crashes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Gelmanscope, everything is blurry. Someone in the room SNORING.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: Weezer, that you?  83.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Hurry! From the second story, a flashlight shines down. It’s Wee

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gelman finds the bed. Nudges the sleeping figure.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: Weezer. Wake up! You gotta wake up! He knocks over a lamp, finally succeeding in turning it o the bed, a giant BULL MASTIFF sits up. This is his room.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: C’mon. Move!

dialogues.speaker: GELMANSCOPE
dialogues.text: An unidentifiable blurry blob sits on the bed. Gelman pus it. It doesn’t move. Gelman feels its head. Its ear. He leans close. A giant black eye comes into focus. The dog BARKS. Gelman SCREAMS. The door flies open.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Daisy! Down! The dog hunches down with a WHIMPER. INT. TOM’S KITCHEN - NIGHT Tom pulls the worm out of the microwave. It’s too hot -- to pass it back from hand to hand.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Ow. Ow. Ow. Ow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom races across the street to a third house. Billy, Gelm Weezer are running up from different sides.  84.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Doors are locked. Windows too. Billy pushes the DOORBELL.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: You didn’t just do that.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: Where are we? Billy pushes the DOORBELL again and again.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: We're going to die. TITLE OVER: 11:58 p.m. While the title’s still on screen, it rolls over to 11:59 hang for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (to Weezer) Nice PJ's.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (to Tom) Sorry I was such a jerk.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We're cool. They bump fists. The door opens. It’s Coach McGuire, in b and a t-shirt. A bear awakened from hibernation. Billy, T and Weezer charge past him into the house. Gelman is left on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: Guys? INT. JOE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT The door BURSTS open. The boys storm in, flipping on the lights. Joe and Alan scurry like roaches. Weezer barricad the door.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Check the time. 11:59. He leans into Joe’s face as he eats the microwaved worm, swallowing just as the clock turns to midnight. Somewhere outside, the town clock is CHIMING, carillon bells ringin  85. Joe pushes Billy away. At the door, POUNDING.

dialogues.speaker: COACH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Joe! What is going on in there?

dialogues.speaker: ALL THE BOYS
dialogues.text: Nothing! Coach McGuire forces the door open, squeezing Weezer agai wall. The boys smile like angels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move among the pews, as the opening hymns play on the Families turn to see the Forresters take their seats.

dialogues.speaker: MOUSY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Broke into three houses, running up and down the stairs like some kind of wild gang. GELMAN’S MOTHER They’re from California. Los Angeles. For all I know, the boy may be a “Crip.” Or a “Blood.”

dialogues.speaker: FEATHERY HAT WOMAN
dialogues.text: And the mother’s the principal, if you can believe that. A woman whispers in Mrs. Saint-Claire’s ear. She looks at Christine, evil schemes hatching. Suzie looks over at Bil He stares coldly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie cuts through the crowd, following Billy. Tom and We block her way like Secret Service agents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy takes out the trash, sorting the recycling into bin feels someone watching him. It’s Suzie. She hands him the styrofoam container.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: I found them in our refrigerator. I didn’t take them. Either Alan or Joe did.  86. Billy fingers through the dirt, scooping out a few small and Big Charley. They’re all okay. He puts the lid back a and starts walking to the house.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Billy, I didn’t mean to screw things up for you. I didn’t have a choice.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Sure you did. You could, (A) Jerk me over, or (B) Not jerk me over.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: You don’t understand how important this election is. To me.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Or, (C) Jerk me over then pretend like it’s not really your fault. Guess what. It is. He leaves and goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine hangs up the phone. Billy comes in through the door. He holds

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Billy, what were you doing last night?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (innocently) When? the container out of sight behind the doorframe.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Say, midnight? Were you running through Gelman’s house and the McGuires? Mitch comes in from the living room, feels the tension an to duck back out. But he’s spotted. Christine waves him o

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gelman just called. Billy and his friends broke into three houses last night after midnight.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: It was before midnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why were you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: We were just screwing around. (pre-emptively) I’m really sorry I did it and I’m taking responsibility for my actions and it won’t happen again. Christine is unimpressed.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Sure. Go to your room.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: But I just apologized.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: That’s not a get-out-of-jail-free card.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: But I got stuff to do with the guys.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Tough. You’re grounded.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: But there’s something I have to do.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You heard your mom. Scoot. 87. Disbelieving this horrible injustice, Billy walks off, ra building. Finally he turns.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: It’s not fair! You wouldn’t be doing this if you were anyone else’s mom. You're just covering your butt because you're the principal.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: No Billy. At school I’m the principal. Here I’m just your mom.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I wish you weren’t my mom. He lets it sting for a second, then charges up the stairs.  88.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Billy, get back here! A door SLAMS on the second floor. Christine keeps Mitch f going after him. He calms.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: He didn’t mean that.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Yes he did. INT. BILLY’S ROOM - DAY A KNOCK at the door. Billy opens it a crack.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Apologize to your mom.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: No. And by the way, thanks for all your help.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You screwed up. You ride the bus, you pay the fare.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’m a political prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Action. Consequences. Think about it. And make up with your mom. Billy shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch helps Christine make the bed. They lay out the comf

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: It’s not centered. You have more on your side.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: That’s intentional. You steal and horde all the covers on your side. Therefore I make the bed with more covers on my side, so that I at least have a fighting chance.  89.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: That’s clever.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: I’m a clever gal. As she tucks the comforter in, he tugs it loose. She pull back, but he yanks it again. A tug of war ensues, Mitch f pulling her onto the bed. As they wrestle, he wraps her u the comforter. Then...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: What was that? Both stop for a second, looking up. There are CLOMPING NO on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Squirrels.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Squirrels?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Gathering nuts for a long, cold winter.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Good idea. Clever squirrels. Mitch pushes her back down on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We RISE alongside the house, past the windows to the roof four boys are hunched around the chimney. Hicks has his binoculars out. Tom has a fishing pole, slowly letting ou down the chimney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy looks up into the fireplace as a hook lowers into v breaded worm attached as bait. He unhooks it. On the mantlepiece, a videocamera is set up. He pushes RECORD.

dialogues.speaker: ON VIDEOTAPE
dialogues.text: Sunday, 4:09 p.m.  90.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: This tape is to prove that I, Billy Forrester, am eating my worm, and nobody and nothing is gonna stop me. He downs it. We PULL BACK, revealing a TV screen. We are. INT. JOE’S FAMILY ROOM - DAY In the darkened room, Joe is watching the worm eating on videotape. He ejects the cassette and trashes it, crackin case and pulling out the insides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mean dog charges the fence as Billy rides past, heading school. The dog YIPES as it hits the end of its chain. Suzie pedals to catch up with Billy, both headed to schoo

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: (cheery) Hey Billy. All ready for the field trip? His glare could freeze lava. Suzie slows, watching as Bil rides away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the busses pull up, a campaign of glances and whispers Suzie looks around self-consciously. Everyone is talking her. Gretchen catches her eye, but quickly looks away. Tom waves Billy over. With his finger to his lips, he pul next-generation Gameboy from his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s the Ultraboy. My uncle got it in Japan. It won’t be here for six months. Billy hits a button and it BEEPS loudly. Tom tucks it awa before anyone sees.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: If my mom sees it, she’ll take it.  gl.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Duh.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: (to the class) There are two busses. Whichever one you take is the one you come back in, understood? Now I’1l be in this bus, and Mrs. Johannsen will be in the other. There’s a stampede heading for Mrs. Johannsen’s bus. Only Cowlicked Kid willingly gets onto Christine’s bus. INT. MRS. JOHANNSEN’S BUS / DRIVING - DAY The boys crowd around Gelman as he plays the Ultraboy.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: (taking it) Don’t bogart the bytes.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: How do I get past the second gate?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I dunno. The instructions are in Japanese. Billy looks up from the huddle to see Suzie looking over He turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine SNEEZES into a kleenex, which blows apart with impact. Eyes watering, nose dripping -- she has hayfever epic proportions. RANGER TOKAMATSU gathers the group near a babbling stream

dialogues.speaker: RANGER TOKAMATSU
dialogues.text: Rockwell National Forest is home to over 3,000 different species, everything from fish to insects, mammals to birds.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You got worms?  92. Some TITTERING in the class.

dialogues.speaker: RANGER TOKAMATSU
dialogues.text: We've got at least five different species of annelid here. Now the thing to keep in mind about an ecosystem like this... As he keeps talking, we push to the back of the group, wh Billy, Tom and Gelman serve as a shield around Hicks as h the Ultraboy. Weezer is helping...

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Shoot the frog! Shoot the frog! Christine looks over. Weezer’s on the hot seat.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: I saw a frog. Over there. Shoot! It’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of kleenex, Christine grabs a leaf to blow her nose. Tokamatsu offers her a bunch of blue flowers.

dialogues.speaker: RANGER TOKAMATSU
dialogues.text: Haricot narcissum. It’s a natual remedy for allergies. That’s why you don’t see bees with sniffles. She takes the flowers. The ranger kneels down to pick som more.

dialogues.speaker: RANGER TOKAMATSU
dialogues.text: When the first settlers came through her, they called it sneeze-wort. The Indians had a different name for it in each season. Half-convinced and desperate, Christine eats a bloom. As chews, we see it’s incredibly bitter. She forces herself swallow.

dialogues.speaker: RANGER TOKAMATSU
dialogues.text: (getting up) Now crush the petals and rub them under your nose. A beat. Christine smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Billy is tying his boot, the class gets ahead of him. shadow falls across him -- Joe. It’s just them.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Even if you do win, you'll still bea loser. You’ll just be King Loser. Billy looks him dead in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (hand to ear) I think I hear your mommy calling. “Billy! Billy, don’t get so far behind.” Billy tries to go around him, but Joe grabs his hat.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: C'mon, grab it. Doncha want it? Doncha? Billy makes no effort to grab it. Frustrated, Joe tosses down the hill to the riverbank.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Y'know what, Joe? I used to be jealous of you, but I’m not anymore. I mean, you're bigger, and faster, and probably smarter. But I’m just better. Billy starts down the hill to retrieve his hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe catches up with the line. Suzie watches him suspiciou

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Where’s Billy?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Fishing. Suzie stops, letting the line pass her. She turns and hea back down the path.

dialogues.speaker: UP AHEAD
dialogues.text: The young hikers pass a “trail closed” barrier, which blo old path. Joe slows, stops. Thinking. He grabs Alan by th belt, holding him back until the rest of the kids are far Joe grabs one end of the barrier, nods to Alan. Confused,  94. nods back.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Take the other side! Alan complies. Together, they drag the barrier across the path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out on a log, Billy retrieves his hat. A few minnows spil of it. As he crosses back to the riverbank, he sees Suzie waiting.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: To apologize, if you’1l let me.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Free country. Do whatever you want. He brushes past her, heading back up to the trail.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: I said I didn’t have a choice, and that’s not true. I did. It’s just, haven’t you ever wanted something so bad you’d do anything to get it, even if it was something stupid? He thinks.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Yes you have!

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Have not.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: You jerk. When somebody apologizes you have to take it.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Fine, I take it. A beat.  95.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: If you don’t mean it, it doesn’t count. Billy shrugs, whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a pace just short of jogging, Billy and Suzie try to c with the group. But the class is nowhere to be seen.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Stop following me!

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: I’m not. I’m following the path. She hurries ahead of Billy. Fine with him. After a beat...

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Shouldn't we be seeing them?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: They're probably over the hill. Besides, they can’t leave without us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids pile onto the two busses. Weezer, Hicks, Tom and Gel continue to wrestle over the Ultraboy, trying to keep it from Christine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By far the rowdier bus. Mrs. Johannsen is working her way a clipboard of names.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JOHANNSEN
dialogues.text: Everybody quiet down please. Please! If anything, they get louder. Alan and Joe are sitting in back.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JOHANNSEN
dialogues.text: Gretchen DeMarco?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Here!  96.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JOHANNSEN
dialogues.text: Billy Forrester?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yo! She checks Billy’s name off her list, reads the next. Nob noticed the voice was wrong. But now the moment of truth.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JOHANNSEN
dialogues.text: Suzie Saint-Claire.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (as Suzie) Here. His voice is eerily perfect. No one bats an eye. Joe smir victoriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Johanssen hands off her clipboard to Christine.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JOHANNSEN
dialogues.text: I got all mine, present and accounted for. Blowing her nose, Christine checks the clipboard. She cou heads last time. It all matches up. She tries to look int second bus, where the kids are swarming all over.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Okay, let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two busses leave Rockwell National Forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy and Suzie are still running.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Where’s the trail?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: It’s here. Right here, see? Well, no, she doesn’t. But she follows him anyway.  97.

dialogues.speaker: LATER, ELSEWHERE
dialogues.text: It’s now clear there really is no trail.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Wait. Wait! I have a compass. It’s in my survival kit. She digs it out of her backpack, orienting herself.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: (pointing) North is that way.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Which way do we want to be? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. It’s only now they realize just how lost they are, alone dark forest of towering trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overhead, thunder RUMBLES. The first big splots of rain f Mitch waits under an umbrella with Katie as KIDS empty ou the first bus. He spots Tom, waves.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: They’re on the other bus. Christine gets off the second bus. The Cowlicked Kid poke in the leg.

dialogues.speaker: COWLICKED KID
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Bye. Don’t forget to check for ticks. The Cowlicked Kid dashes away, dorky with love.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You're cheating on me, aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: He’s too much man for me. Where’s Billy?  98.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I thought he was on your bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan gets in, chewing on the cord of his hooded sweatshir

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Where’s your sister?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I dunno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine walks up behind Tom and the gang, who don’t hav to hide the Ultraboy.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Was Billy on your bus?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. The other boys shake their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Johannsen looks through the clipboard one more time. takes it away from her.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Was he on the bus or not?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JOHANNSEN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I don’t know what he looks like. Mrs. Saint-Claire comes up from behind.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Where is Suzie? Suzie Saint-Claire. Christine returns from the bike racks.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: (to Mitch) He wasn’t on the bus.  99.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Where is my daughter! A CRACK of thunder carries us back to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A treeful of crows fly off. It’s just starting to drizzle Suzie blows a shrill plastic WHISTLE. Counting to five, s blows again.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Would you stop that!

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: It’s so the rescue team can find us. She BLOWS again.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What we oughta do is build traps to catch rabbits.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Duh. For food.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: I have a Power Bar. I'11 split it with you. She digs it out of the pack. Billy takes the whole kit fr and start rooting through it. It’s very complete: bandaid fishing line, a lightstick -- everything but...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You don’t have any matches.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Alan has a way of finding matches.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What kind of crappy survival kit doesn’t have matches?

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: (taking it back) My survival kit.  100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s now raining steadily. Kneeling in the rain, Billy has built a perfect campfire, the flame. He strikes rocks together, over and over. Not a spark. Sitting in the root hollow of a giant tree, Suzie neatly her foil emergency blanket. Still striking his rocks, Bil watches, wet and annoyed. Suzie tucks the blanket in around her, snug as a bug in a She cracks the lightstick and shakes it. It glowly warmly Billy finally abandons his fire. Swallowing his pride, he over to Suzie.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I made fun of your survival kit.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Do you accept my apology?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Yes. And I’m not just saying it.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Then I accept yours. She scoots over to make room for him under the blanket. O he’s settled, she hands him the plastic whistle. He wipes off and blows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now crowded with sherriff’s vehicles, a second news van j pulling in. Jumping from a pickup truck, search dogs HOWL sniff. High-powered FLASHLIGHTS catch the rain. MEN and WOMEN in ponchos gather around a canopy set up as base.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE JACKSON
dialogues.text: We're going to divide into teams of three and fan out. Now, each team will have a radio and a GPS, so we’ll know what you covered. Christine WHACKS her flashlight to get it working. Mitch  101. her his.

dialogues.speaker: BY A NEWS VAN
dialogues.text: Mrs. Saint-Claire is dragging her husband by the arm as h attempts to get a videotape out of his camera. She SNAPS him to give her the tape.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. You! Reporter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom sits right in front of the TV.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s on! On the couch, Katie slouches on Tom’s grandmother as they the news.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: .--where almost fifty searchers have gathered to look for two children who became separated from a school field trip.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCREEN
dialogues.text: video of Billy and Suzie at the ballpark. Katie rushes to the screen, putting her hands on her brot face. INT. WEEZER’S HOUSE - NIGHT He’s watching too.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: C'mon man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his PJ's, the Cowlicked Kid peers through the staircas the TV in the living room. INT. JOE’S HOUSE - NIGHT Alan looks over to Joe, who is reading Sports Illustrated  102.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coach McGuire leads a team to the left. We can hear a HELICOPTER in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Billy! Suzie!

dialogues.speaker: ELSEWHERE
dialogues.text: Mitch leads a team to the right. The HELICOPTER is gettin closer.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Billy! Suzie!

dialogues.speaker: ELSEWHERE
dialogues.text: Christine waits impatiently while Ranger Tokamatsu radios their position. The helicopter flies overhead, its search blinding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet here. Suzie looks into Billy’s worm container.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: That’s Big Charley. He’s for last.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: What’s this one’s name?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I dunno. Number 14. He’s the one I’m supposed to eat today. She offers it to him, go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Joe has to see me eat it. That’s the rule.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Why do boys always make so many rules for things?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: If you don’t have rules, how do you know who won? He puts the container back in his bag.  103.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: If it means anything, I always knew you'd finish the bet, no matter who tried to stop you. Even me. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You're not going to like kiss me or something.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Good. That would be gross. Very faintly first, but there -- that SOUND.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: It’s a helicopter!

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’m from Los Angeles. That’s a helicopter. He grabs the shiny blanket and starts waving it around wi trying to catch the helicopter’s attention. Suzie joins h waving her arms and SHOUTING in the rain. Finally the searchlight hits them, and holds. They do a h and idiotic dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch and Christine are pacing when Billy comes out of th shadows ahead of his rescue party. Mitch drops his coffee run and grab him, carrying him upside down.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: (upside down) Are you alright? Billy nods.

dialogues.speaker: A LITTLE LATER
dialogues.text: The sheriffs are collecting radios, striking base. Mitch  104. shaking each and every person's hand. With a blanket and cup of cocoa, Billy sits with his mom. the far side of the parking lot, the Saint-Claire’s are b interviewed by a TV station.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Mom, what time is it?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Eleven fifty-five. She gets up to thank Ranger Tokamatsu, who is leaving. Bi stands, takes his backpack. He starts walking towards the news van...

dialogues.speaker: TITLE OVER BLACK
dialogues.text: We return to Billy, still walking this way. In the foreground...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I held out hope, because all you can do is hope. You hope and you pray.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Are you on live? The Reporter ignores him. The CAMERAMAN motions for him t out of the shot.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: This is Billy. He was with me. Suddenly he’s worth talking to. Mrs. Saint-Claire is appa

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: You're Billy Forrester.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Yes I am. And I’m eating a worm. The fourteenth worm squiggles in his fingers, raw and dir very much alive. He eats it whole, chewing four times and swallowing. He opens his mouth wide so the TV audience ca he did it. INT. TOM’S HOUSE - NIGHT Tom CHEERS.  105. INT. WEEZER’S HOUSE - NIGHT Weezer CLAPS, big blubbery tears coming. INT. COWLICKED KID’S HOUSE - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: COWLICKED KID
dialogues.text: Yes! INT. JOE’S HOUSE - NIGHT Joe turns the TV off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch talks to Billy over the seat.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: So you made a bet to eat worms?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Fifteen worms in fifteen days. And you wouldn't believe all the crap Joe pulled. I showed ‘em no one and nothing was gonna stop me. Mitch isn’t as proud as Billy hoped.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I mean, it all worked out great in the end. Through the windows, we see Mrs. Saint-Claire yelling at Christine. We can’t hear what’s being shouted, but it’s n hard to imagine. Christine is walking to the car, not fighting back. That makes Mrs. Saint-Claire angrier. As Christine opens the d

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (shouting) After tomorrow, you won’t have a job! Christine shuts the door, pretending that didn’t happen. looks at Mitch looking at Christine.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: (mock chipper) Let’s go home.  106. INT. HALLWAY / BILLY’S ROOM - NIGHT In his pajamas, Billy leans out the doorway. His parents’ is open a crack. He can hear them TALKING inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy's parents are getting ready for bed.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You don’t honestly think she can get you fired?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Okay. First you have the Boston Tea Party happening in Billy’s class. Then I lose two kids on a field trip -- two kids, including my own son. Then to top it off, my kid eats a live worm on television. I don’t come across looking especially responsible. She shuts the hallway door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a beat, Billy shuts his door. INT. BILLY’S ROOM - NIGHT Billy sleeps fitfully, tossing and turning. We HEAR a helicopter WHOOSHING past outside. Radio CHATTER. The gro RUMBLES. Awakened, Billy climbs out of bed, looks out the window --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeeps and Humvees line the streets. SOLDIERS scatter. A tank SMASHES through the neighbor’s picket fence. Searchlights criss-cross the night sky. In his pajamas, Billy walks amid the troops as marines st coils of barbed wire across the street. A Patton-like Gen barks orders into a walkie-talkie.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got a level three annelid intruder. Looks like a big one. 107. A BLIP moves closer on a radar screen. A squint-eyed SCIE studies the printout.

dialogues.speaker: SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: It’s female, no question. It doesn’t make sense. The only reason she'd rise is it someone consumed one of her young.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: Dear God. What kind of fool would eat a worm?

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He did it! SPIN to see Joe and Alan, both in camouflage.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: We told him not to.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: He wouldn’t believe us. An EXPLOSION in the distance. The pavement buckles as giant plows a tunnel up from under the street.

dialogues.speaker: SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: It’s centering on the boy.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: For the love of God, run! Billy turns and flees --

dialogues.speaker: OVER FENCES --
dialogues.text: through dark BACK ALLEYS --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: something Empty and echoey. Panicked, Billy tries classroom doors. Locked. Locked. Locked. We HEAR a monstrous BELLOW as the beast slithers down the adjoining hallway. We see its reflection in the trophy ca  108. Finally, an unlocked door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy SLAMS the door shut, tripping over the desks in the darkness. He climbs up on the counter by the outside wind Through the narrow window in the door, we see a glistenin form slide past, segment after segment, seemingly endless must fill the entire hall. Finally it passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy pokes his head out. At the end of the hall, he sees Christine BANGING on doors, panicked, looking for him.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Billy? She checks in a window. Behind her rises a_six-foot circu mouth, jagged teeth glinting. The worm has returned.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: But it’s too late. We stay on Billy as he watches his mom swallowed. INT. BILLY’S ROOM - NIGHT Billy sits bolt upright in bed, shaking. Catches his brea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy sits down on the floor, jiggling the handle on the Katie looks in from the hallway, dragging Mr. Bobo.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Go away Katie. Amscray. She comes in, still staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You don’t know it yet, but I’ve screwed up everything. Without even trying. Katie hands him the sock monkey and hugs him. She walks b out, leaving Billy alone in his quandary.  109.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rinsing his bowl in the sink, Billy watches his mom leave work. INT. BILLY’S ROOM - DAY Wearing one shoe, searching for the other. Lying on the f he looks under the bed. He finds the shoe, and also the t monkey Suzie won for him. He winds it up, watching it SMA cymbals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking down the row, the boys silently clap for him. The Cowlicked Kid practices taking his bike in and out of its to-be home. As Joe arrives, the Kid moves his bike. But he’s not hurr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls crowd around the once Miss Overholser, newly re They all admire her gorgeous ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom waves Billy over to sit with him. On her side of the Suzie is telling the girls about her night, complete with thunder and raining fingers. She catches Billy's eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weezer inhales an electric blue Slurpee. He suddenly stop slurping, his forehead quivering. Nose crinkling. He CRIE at the onset of a catastrophic brain freeze.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (ignoring Weezer) You know they’re having some big parents meeting tonight.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s perfect. While they’re at that, we’re gonna meet at 7:30 on the playground for the last worm. Paying for his candybar, Billy nods half-heartedly. makes an amazing find among the magazines...

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: Spider Marine versus Swamp Rat. Limited edition.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: That’s forty bucks.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: I have the money. Least, I’1l have it tomorrow. 110. Gelman He looks to Tom, who shoots him a deadly look. Billy look Tom.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Okay. We didn’t want to tell you because we thought it might jinx you. Sorta like how you made the bet with Joe, some of us made little side bets of our own.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You bet on me?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Mostly. Some people bet against you. Billy is reeling.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: If you finish, Joe owes me thirty and Hicks owes me twenty. Billy looks to Hicks, farther back at the newstand. hide.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (to Tom) How much did you bet?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Altogether? Ninety for, twenty against. (off reaction) I was just covering the spread. He tries to  111. Weezer's brain thaws, popping back to consciousness. He b slurping again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie is standing by the cabinets, crying for no particul reason.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Dad, do you think if... Katie suddenly starts WAILING as only two year-olds can. picks her up, but it doesn’t help. He calls upstairs...

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Honey, we gotta go now or we’re going to be late. He walks off with Katie, trying to calm her. Billy is lef alone in his quandary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the podium, a SQUEAK.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: If we could get started. Everyone please take a seat. A crowd of PARENTS mills about, slowly coming to their ch Mitch and Christine are there, along with Katie. Overwhel frustrated, Christine starts to get up to go for the podi Mitch holds her back. Mrs. Saint-Claire is at a table with six SCHOOL BOARD MEM She relies on her note-cards.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Parents, friends, distinguished members of the school board, I want to thank you all for coming here tonight. I’m sure most of you are probably aware of the difficulties this school has been having over the past two weeks, and are probably concerned. Lord knows I was. But I remind you, we’re not here to point fingers or to find fault. Instead of being negative, we need to be positive. And I’m sure once we are positive, we’ll know what has to be done.  112.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy zips up his jacket. The clock reads 7:20. INT. COWLICKED KID’S HOUSE - NIGHT While his SISTER makes out with SOME GUY on the couch, th sneaks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan and Suzie leave at the same time, but certainly not together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An autumn wind sweeps through a lone elm, swaying against night sky. Swings dangle like pendulums. Softly at first, we hear DRUMS. Faces emerge from the dar at the edge of the playground: Suzie and Alan. Gretchen. Cowlicked Kid, walking his bike. They are all gathering. As the drums grow LOUDER, we see the source. Hicks and We are banging on the playground slide, working up a good be Gelman slowly turns the merry-go-round. Billy sits at the center, blindfolded. As the kids gather, we see the whole class has come to be witness. Tom holds the worm container. Joe stands alone. At Tom’s signal, Gelman stops. Billy removes his blindfol Gets up, woozy. He starts walking toward the group. As th SLIDE-DRUMMING becomes thunderous, we enter SLOW MOTION.. Tom digs Big Charley out of the dirt. Billy walks. Gelman leads a silent cheer of “Bil-EE! Bil-EE!" The Cowlicked K smiles in anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In this strange and forbidding world, one creature walks alone. Suzie watches him, her expression harder to read. Billy w

dialogues.speaker: BILLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He follows a compass only he can see, to a place he does not know.  113. Mitch is walking right behind him, talking into his ear.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Action. Consequences. Think about it. Billy blinks and Mitch vanishes. Still walking, he looks the crowd of CHEERING kids. Christine is among them.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Sometimes doing the right thing means being a dork. He focusses only on Tom, holding the worm, a few steps aw But then Tom changes into the Cook.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What do you do when there’s two right things to do?

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: That’s the hardest part. Deciding what’s more important. Billy takes the worm from him. All sound goes away. We ju hear Billy’s BREATH, his HEARTBEAT. He holds the wrigglin in his hand, looking across a sea of frozen faces. Time h stopped.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER VOICE
dialogues.text: Hey. Hey! Kid! Billy looks down at his hand. Big Charley is standing up, talking to him.

dialogues.speaker: BIG CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Are you gonna eat me or what? I been waiting fifteen days, and lemme tell ya, that’s a long time for a worm. Look at me. What’d’I gotta live for? Nothin! I live in dirt! But this. This is my one chance at history, baby. I got a name! Me and Jimminy Cricket. Only bugs with names. (leaning closer) Kid, we got a common destiny. I’m pleadin’ with ya. Eat me!

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I can’t. Like that, the spell is broken. We’re out of Billyvision.  114.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What do you mean you can’t?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I can’t until I know my mom is okay. This is my fault and I have to fix it. He pockets the worm.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Because I have a code. He starts toward the school, alone. The Cowlicked Kid is shocked and crushed.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: What the hell is a code? Only Suzie understands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulling out a file, Mrs. Saint-Claire continues her prose

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: So far I’ve focussed on professional issues: her lackluster discipline, poor communication skills, gross irresponsiblity... One of the board members, a NEBBISHY GUY, is shaking his get it to write. Mrs. Saint-Claire hands him hers.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (leaning close) Poor communication, gross irresponsiblity. He writes that down. She smiles. Christine rolls her eyes

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: But to really understand the problem, we need to look at the issue of personal character. What kind of person is Christine Forrester? What kind of mother is she? Christine can’t take any more. She stands.  115.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Stop.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: What kind of mother allows her son to eat worms?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: You can question my credentials as teacher or a principal, but don’t you ever question my ability to be a mother. Mrs. Saint-Claire smiles to herself. There’s a dead space silence filled with SQUEAKING chairs and nervous RUSTLING ECHO as the gymnasium doors open. It’s Billy. He’s spooked by how many people there are, bu starts to cross to the podium.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: The prodigal son returns.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Billy, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. I got it all figured out. Mitch covers his eyes. At the podium, he motions for Mrs. Claire to step aside. With a “would-you-look-at-this,” sh does.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: My name is Billy Forrester and I gotta explain. This whole thing started fifteen days ago because I didn’t want everyone to think I was a dork, when really I was a dork for caring what everyone thought. Anyway, I made this bet to eat fifteen worms in fifteen days. She didn’t know anything about it. And if you think you know everything your kids do, then you're just stupid. Not exactly winning over the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I guess my point... All heads turn as the DOORS open again. It’s Suzie. Mrs. Claire is alarmed.  Behind Suzie, it’s Tom. class comes in. Parents start BUZZING. He pulls wriggles Angle on Christine.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I guess my point is this is a kid thing and you're trying to treat it like it’s a grown up thing and it’s not. I mean, we were the ones who screwed up the classroom, and Suzie and I were the ones who got lost. So if you’re gonna blame somebody, you gotta blame us. Blame me. My mom taught me to take responsibility for my actions, and that’s what I’m gonna do. Big Charley out of his pocket, sets it down. around on the table.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: This is the fifteenth worm. And as much junk as I went through to eat the first fourteen, I'd give it all up for her. She’s my mom, and I love her. But she’s also a damn good principal, and you'd be stupid to get rid of her just because her kid eats worms.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Damn right.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Woo-hoo!

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Oh. That’s it. little proud. She waves Billy over.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Well.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: (low) Billy, I really appreciate what you’re trying to do. But you don’t have to give up the bet for me.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I want to. 116. And Weezer, Hicks, Gelman -- the whole The worm As bad as this is, she can’t help but be a ANGLE ON Mrs. Saint-Claire, basking in the glory of her v She's about to speak when Coach McGuire stands up.  117.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: I'd just like to say, I love my kid. And one day, I hope he learns what Billy Forrester did, because let me tell you. As a parent, I could never be prouder.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE JACKSON
dialogues.text: You said it.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN IN THE AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Half the time, I don’t know what my kids are up to. You just hope they have a sense of what’s right and what’s wrong.

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: (pointing to Christine) If you could help me teach my kids that, I would double your salary. TOM’S GRANDMOTHER All in favor of seeing this kid eat his worm? Hands go up in the audience, a few at first, then more. A more. It’s almost unanimous. The kids CHEER. Joe slinks b against the wall. Mrs. Saint-Claire stares in disbelief. Weezer starts a lo cheer: “Bill-EE. Bill-EE.”

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (to his parents) Can I? Mitch and Christine nod. Billy walks back to the front. He takes Big Charley, tosses it up in the air. Catches it his mouth, swallowing him whole. The kids CHEER wildly, swarming the podium. Weezer is in tears. Hicks pats him o back.

dialogues.speaker: GELMAN
dialogues.text: I wish I had a code.

dialogues.speaker: COUNCILMEMBER
dialogues.text: Meeting adjourned. He BANGS the gavel. Gretchen hugs Christine from behind. Cowlicked Kid brushes past Joe. They lock stares.  118.

dialogues.speaker: COWLICKED KID
dialogues.text: See you at the bike racks. The crowd parts to reveal Suzie. Billy offers her a hand.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Thanks, man. She takes his hand, then jerks him in for a big kiss righ the lips. The boys are shocked.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Way to go, Billy Forrester. Billy stares straight ahead, dumbfounded and horrified. M nudges Christine -- that’s my kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The once Miss Overholser unfolds the last ballot. On the chalkboard, she circles Suzie’s name. The class CHEERS. B and Suzie share a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie runs across the lawn, crashing into another TODDLER Mitch chases after them. There are four other YOUNGSTERS playing on the lawn. MOVE PAST Mitch to reveal a sign: “Forrester Day Care Center.” INT. CHRISTINE’S OFFICE - DAY Kicking back with some Snapple, Christine and Mother Jack LAUGH their heads off. Mother Jackson fans herself. Then both start laughing harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the lunch line, Billy takes his tacos.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: We still on for Nintendo?

dialogues.speaker: THE COOK
dialogues.text: You got it.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE LUNCH TABLE
dialogues.text: Billy sits in his new seat, surveying his kingdom. Joe an are banished to the center, where Alan is downing sugar p  119. The Cowlicked Kid walks up.

dialogues.speaker: COWLICKED KID
dialogues.text: Move it or lose it. Joe slides down to make room. Weezer pulls the top on his can, but the tab rips off. Gretchen takes the can from hi bites into it with her braces. Weezer is impressed.

dialogues.speaker: WEEZER
dialogues.text: Wanna see what I can do with that Jello? All is well in the fifth grade. Tom leans close.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We gotta start thinking about the future. What else would you be willing to eat? FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEME MUSIC plays. BOB SAGET is wearing a tuxedo.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SAGET
dialogues.text: And now to announce our grand prize winner! Drum roll, please. A snare drum rolls down the steps. The audience LAUGHS robotically.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SAGET
dialogues.text: I knew that would happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With no makeup and hair in curlers, Mrs. Saint-Claire gat dirty laundry while talking on the cordless phone. Sets t basket at the top of the stairs, tucks a kleenex in her s  120.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: If that [BEEP!] thinks she can take over the school, she doesn’t know who she’s dealing with. (yelling) Alan, what did you get on this shirt! Alan runs past, hair in soapy spikes. Makes dinosaur NOIS

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SAINT-CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (to camera) Henry, put that [BEEP!]-ing thing down. (to phone) So help me I’1l break her legs. She heads for the stairs, tripping over the laundry baske Reaches for the railing. Misses. She CRASHES down the stairs, bouncing fifteen times, comi rest on the landing. Looking up, she’s SMACKED by the lau basket. Rolls the rest of the way down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience LAUGHS. A FAT WOMAN goes into hysterics. Bob Saget kneels down next to Mr. Saint-Claire with a check.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SAGET
dialogues.text: I hope this makes for a merry Christmas. You’ve already had a great fall! The audience ROARS. We PAN OVER to Mrs. Saint-Claire in a body cast. She bares her teeth. But she’s not really smil FADE OUT.
